books.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:1
verses.text: Chapter I.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:2
verses.text: —Exhortation to Abandon the Impious Mysteries of Idolatry for the Adoration of the Divine Word and God the Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:3
verses.text: Amphion of Thebes and Arion of Methymna were both minstrels, and both were renowned in story.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:4
verses.text: They are celebrated in song to this day in the chorus of the Greeks; the one for having allured the fishes, and the other for having surrounded Thebes with walls by the power of music.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:5
verses.text: Another, a Thracian, a cunning master of his art (he also is the subject of a Hellenic legend), tamed the wild beasts by the mere might of song; and transplanted trees—oaks—by music.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:6
verses.text: I might tell you also the story of another, a brother to these—the subject of a myth, and a minstrel—Eunomos the Locrian and the Pythic grasshopper.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:7
verses.text: A solemn Hellenic assembly had met at Pytho, to celebrate the death of the Pythic serpent, when Eunomos sang the reptile's epitaph.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:8
verses.text: Whether his ode was a hymn in praise of the serpent, or a dirge, I am not able to say.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:9
verses.text: But there was a contest, and Eunomos was playing the lyre in the summer time: it was when the grasshoppers, warmed by the sun, were chirping beneath the leaves along the hills; but they were singing not to that dead dragon, but to God All-wise,—a lay unfettered by rule, better than the numbers of Eunomos.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:10
verses.text: The Locrian breaks a string.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:11
verses.text: The grasshopper sprang on the neck of the instrument, and sang on it as on a branch; and the minstrel, adapting his strain to the grasshopper's song, made up for the want of the missing string.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:12
verses.text: The grasshopper then was attracted by the song of Eunomos, as the fable represents, according to which also a brazen statue of Eunomos with his lyre, and the Locrian's ally in the contest, was erected at Pytho.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:13
verses.text: But of its own accord it flew to the lyre, and of its own accord sang, and was regarded by the Greeks as a musical performer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:14
verses.text: How, let me ask, have you believed vain fables and supposed animals to be charmed by music; while Truth's shining face alone, as would seem, appears to you disguised, and is looked on with incredulous eyes? And so Cithaeron, and Helicon, and the mountains of the Odrysi, and the initiatory rites of the Thracians, mysteries of deceit, are hallowed and celebrated in hymns.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:15
verses.text: For me, I am pained at such calamities as form the subjects of tragedy, though but myths; but by you the records of miseries are turned into dramatic compositions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:16
verses.text: But the dramas and the raving poets, now quite intoxicated, let us crown with ivy; and distracted outright as they are, in Bacchic fashion, with the satyrs, and the frenzied rabble, and the rest of the demon crew, let us confine to Cithaeron and Helicon, now antiquated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:17
verses.text: But let us bring from above out of heaven, Truth, with Wisdom in all its brightness, and the sacred prophetic choir, down to the holy mount of God; and let Truth, darting her light to the most distant points, cast her rays all around on those that are involved in darkness, and deliver men from delusion, stretching out her very strong right hand, which is wisdom, for their salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:18
verses.text: And raising their eyes, and looking above, let them abandon Helicon and Cithaeron, and take up their abode in Sion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:19
verses.text: "For out of Sion shall go forth the law, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem,"—the celestial Word, the true athlete crowned in the theatre of the whole universe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:20
verses.text: What my Eunomos sings is not the measure of Terpander, nor that of Capito, nor the Phrygian, nor Lydian, nor Dorian, but the immortal measure of the new harmony which bears God's name—the new, the Levitical song.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:21
verses.text: "Soother of pain, calmer of wrath, producing forgetfulness of all ills".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:22
verses.text: Sweet and true is the charm of persuasion which blends with this strain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:23
verses.text: To me, therefore, that Thracian Orpheus, that Theban, and that Methymnaean,—men,  and yet unworthy of the name,—seem to have been deceivers, who, under the pretence of poetry corrupting human life, possessed by a spirit of artful sorcery for purposes of destruction, celebrating crimes in their orgies, and making human woes the materials of religious worship, were the first to entice men to idols; nay, to build up the stupidity of the nations with blocks of wood and stone,—that is, statues and images,—subjecting to the yoke of extremest bondage the truly noble freedom of those who lived as free citizens under heaven by their songs and incantations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:24
verses.text: But not such is my song, which has come to loose, and that speedily, the bitter bondage of tyrannizing demons; and leading us back to the mild and loving yoke of piety, recalls to heaven those that had been cast prostrate to the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:25
verses.text: It alone has tamed men, the most intractable of animals; the frivolous among them answering to the fowls of the air, deceivers to reptiles, the irascible to lions, the voluptuous to swine, the rapacious to wolves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:26
verses.text: The silly are stocks and stones, and still more senseless than stones is a man who is steeped in ignorance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:27
verses.text: As our witness, let us adduce the voice of prophecy accordant with truth, and bewailing those who are crushed in ignorance and folly: "For God is able of these stones to raise up children to Abraham;" and He, commiserating their great ignorance and hardness of heart who are petrified against the truth, has raised up a seed of piety, sensitive to virtue, of those stones—of the nations, that is, who trusted in stones.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:28
verses.text: Again, therefore, some venomous and false hypocrites, who plotted against righteousness, He once called "a brood of vipers".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:29
verses.text: But if one of those serpents even is willing to repent, and follows the Word, he becomes a man of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:30
verses.text: Others he figuratively calls wolves, clothed in sheep-skins, meaning thereby monsters of rapacity in human form.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:31
verses.text: And so all such most savage beasts, and all such blocks of stone, the celestial song has transformed into tractable men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:32
verses.text: "For even we ourselves were sometime foolish, disobedient, deceived, serving divers lusts and pleasures, living in malice and envy, hateful, hating one another".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:33
verses.text: Thus speaks the apostolic Scripture: "But after that the kindness and love of God our saviour to man appeared, not by works of righteousness which we have done, but according to His mercy, He saved us".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:34
verses.text: Behold the might of the new song! It has made men out of stones, men out of beasts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:35
verses.text: Those, moreover, that were as dead, not being partakers of the true life, have come to life again, simply by becoming listeners to this song.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:36
verses.text: It also composed the universe into melodious order, and tuned the discord of the elements to harmonious arrangement, so that the whole world might become harmony.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:37
verses.text: It let loose the fluid ocean, and yet has prevented it from encroaching on the land.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:38
verses.text: The earth, again, which had been in a state of commotion, it has established, and fixed the sea as its boundary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:39
verses.text: The violence of fire it has softened by the atmosphere, as the Dorian is blended with the Lydian strain; and the harsh cold of the air it has moderated by the embrace of fire, harmoniously arranging these the extreme tones of the universe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:40
verses.text: And this deathless strain,—the support of the whole and the harmony of all,—reaching from the centre to the circumference, and from the extremities to the central part, has harmonized this universal frame of things, not according to the Thracian music, which is like that invented by Jubal, but according to the paternal counsel of God, which fired the zeal of David.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:41
verses.text: And He who is of David, and yet before him, the Word of God, despising the lyre and harp, which are but lifeless instruments, and having tuned by the Holy Spirit the universe, and especially man,—who, composed of body and soul, is a universe in miniature,—makes melody to God on this instrument of many tones; and to this instrument—I mean man—he sings accordant: "For thou art my harp, and pipe, and temple".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:42
verses.text: —a harp for harmony—a pipe by reason of the Spirit—a temple by reason of the word; so that the first may sound, the second breathe, the third contain the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:43
verses.text: And David the king, the harper whom we mentioned a little above, who exhorted to the truth and dissuaded from idols, was so far from celebrating demons in song, that in reality they were driven away by his music.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:44
verses.text: Thus, when Saul was plagued with a demon, he cured him by merely playing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:45
verses.text: A beautiful breathing instrument of music the Lord made man, after His own image.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:46
verses.text: And He Himself also, surely, who is the supramundane Wisdom, the celestial Word, is the all-harmonious, melodious, holy instrument of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:47
verses.text: What, then, does this instrument—the Word of God, the Lord, the New Song—desire? To open the eyes of the blind, and unstop the ears of the deaf, and to lead the lame or the erring to righteousness, to exhibit God to the foolish, to put a stop to corruption, to conquer death, to reconcile disobedient children to their father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:48
verses.text: The instrument of God loves mankind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:49
verses.text: The Lord pities, instructs, exhorts, admonishes, saves, shields, and of His bounty promises us the kingdom of heaven as a reward for learning; and the only advantage He reaps is, that we are  saved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:50
verses.text: For wickedness feeds on men's destruction; but truth, like the bee, harming nothing, delights only in the salvation of men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:51
verses.text: You have, then, God's promise; you have His love: become partaker of His grace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:52
verses.text: And do not suppose the song of salvation to be new, as a vessel or a house is new.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:53
verses.text: For "before the morning star it was;" and "in the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:54
verses.text: Error seems old, but truth seems a new thing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:55
verses.text: Whether, then, the Phrygians are shown to be the most ancient people by the goats of the fable; or, on the other hand, the Arcadians by the poets, who describe them as older than the moon; or, finally, the Egyptians by those who dream that this land first gave birth to gods and men: yet none of these at least existed before the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:56
verses.text: But before the foundation of the world were we, who, because destined to be in Him, pre-existed in the eye of God before,—we the rational creatures of the Word of God, on whose account we date from the beginning; for "in the beginning was the Word".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:57
verses.text: Well, inasmuch as the Word was from the first, He was and is the divine source of all things; but inasmuch as He has now assumed the name Christ, consecrated of old, and worthy of power, he has been called by me the New Song.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:58
verses.text: This Word, then, the Christ, the cause of both our being at first (for He was in God) and of our well-being, this very Word has now appeared as man, He alone being both, both God and man—the Author of all blessings to us; by whom we, being taught to live well, are sent on our way to life eternal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:59
verses.text: For, according to that inspired apostle of the Lord, "the grace of God which bringeth salvation hath appeared to all men, teaching us, that, denying ungodliness and worldly lusts, we should live soberly, righteously, and godly, in this present world; looking for the blessed hope, and appearing of the glory of the great God and our Saviour Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:60
verses.text: This is the New Song, the manifestation of the Word that was in the beginning, and before the beginning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:61
verses.text: The Saviour, who existed before, has in recent days appeared.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:62
verses.text: He, who is in Him that truly is, has appeared; for the Word, who "was with God," and by whom all things were created, has appeared as our Teacher.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:63
verses.text: The Word, who in the beginning bestowed on us life as Creator when He formed us, taught us to live well when He appeared as our Teacher; that as God He might afterwards conduct us to the life which never ends.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:64
verses.text: He did not now for the first time pity us for our error; but He pitied us from the first, from the beginning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:65
verses.text: But now, at His appearance, lost as we already were, He accomplished our salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:66
verses.text: For that wicked reptile monster, by his enchantments, enslaves and plagues men even till now; inflicting, as seems to me, such barbarous vengeance on them as those who are said to bind the captives to corpses till they rot together.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:67
verses.text: This wicked tyrant and serpent, accordingly, binding fast with the miserable chain of superstition whomsoever he can draw to his side from their birth, to stones, and stocks, and images, and such like idols, may with truth be said to have taken and buried living men with those dead idols, till both suffer corruption together.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:68
verses.text: Therefore (for the seducer is one and the same) he that at the beginning brought Eve down to death, now brings thither the rest of mankind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:69
verses.text: Our ally and helper, too, is one and the same—the Lord, who from the beginning gave revelations by prophecy, but now plainly calls to salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:70
verses.text: In obedience to the apostolic injunction, therefore, let us flee from "the prince of the power of the air, the spirit that now worketh in the children of disobedience," and let us run to the Lord the saviour, who now exhorts to salvation, as He has ever done, as He did by signs and wonders in Egypt and the desert, both by the bush and the cloud, which, through the favour of divine love, attended the Hebrews like a handmaid.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:71
verses.text: By the fear which these inspired He addressed the hard-hearted; while by Moses, learned in all wisdom, and Isaiah, lover of truth, and the whole prophetic choir, in a way appealing more to reason, He turns to the Word those who have ears to hear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:72
verses.text: Sometimes He upbraids, and sometimes He threatens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:73
verses.text: Some men He mourns over, others He addresses with the voice of song, just as a good physician treats some of his patients with cataplasms, some with rubbing, some with fomentations; in one case cuts open with the lancet, in another cauterizes, in another amputates, in order if possible to cure the patient's diseased part or member.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:74
verses.text: The Saviour has many tones of voice, and many methods for the salvation of men; by threatening He admonishes, by upbraiding He converts, by bewailing He pities, by the voice of song He cheers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:75
verses.text: He spake by the burning bush, for the men of that day needed signs and wonders.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:76
verses.text: He awed men by the fire when He made flame to burst from the pillar of cloud—a token at once of grace and fear: if you obey, there is the light; if you disobey, there is the fire; but since humanity is nobler than the pillar or the bush, after them the prophets uttered their voice,—the Lord Himself speaking in Isaiah,  in Elias,—speaking Himself by the mouth of the prophets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:77
verses.text: But if thou dost not believe the prophets, but supposest both the men and the fire a myth, the Lord Himself shall speak to thee, "who, being in the form of God, thought it not robbery to be equal with God, but humbled Himself,"—He, the merciful God, exerting Himself to save man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:78
verses.text: And now the Word Himself clearly speaks to thee, shaming thy unbelief; yea, I say, the Word of God became man, that thou mayest learn from man how man may become God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:79
verses.text: Is it not then monstrous, my friends, that while God is ceaselessly exhorting us to virtue, we should spurn His kindness and reject salvation?  Does not John also invite to salvation, and is he not entirely a voice of exhortation? Let us then ask him, "Who of men art thou, and whence?" He will not say Elias.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:80
verses.text: He will deny that he is Christ, but will profess himself to be "a voice crying in the wilderness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:81
verses.text: Who, then, is John? In a word, we may say, "The beseeching voice of the Word crying in the wilderness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:82
verses.text: What criest thou, O voice? Tell us also.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:83
verses.text: "Make straight the paths of the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:84
verses.text: John is the forerunner, and that voice the precursor of the Word; an inviting voice, preparing for salvation,—a voice urging men on to the inheritance of the heavens, and through which the barren and the desolate is childless no more.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:85
verses.text: This fecundity the angel's voice foretold; and this voice was also the precursor of the Lord preaching glad tidings to the barren woman, as John did to the wilderness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:86
verses.text: By reason of this voice of the Word, therefore, the barren woman bears children, and the desert becomes fruitful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:87
verses.text: The two voices which heralded the Lord's—that of the angel and that of John—intimate, as I think, the salvation in store for us to be, that on the appearance of this Word we should reap, as the fruit of this productiveness, eternal life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:88
verses.text: The Scripture makes this all clear, by referring both the voices to the same thing: "Let her hear who has not brought forth, and let her who has not had the pangs of childbirth utter her voice: for more are the children of the desolate, than of her who hath an husband".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:89
verses.text: The angel announced to us the glad tidings of a husband.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:90
verses.text: John entreated us to recognise the husbandman, to seek the husband.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:91
verses.text: For this husband of the barren woman, and this husbandman of the desert—who filled with divine power the barren woman and the desert—is one and the same.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:92
verses.text: For because many were the children of the mother of noble rule, yet the Hebrew woman, once blessed with many children, was made childless because of unbelief: the barren woman receives the husband, and the desert the husbandman; then both become mothers through the word, the one of fruits, the other of believers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:93
verses.text: But to the unbelieving the barren and the desert are still reserved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:94
verses.text: For this reason John, the herald of the Word, besought men to make themselves ready against the coming of the Christ of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:95
verses.text: And it was this which was signified by the dumbness of Zacharias, which waited for fruit in the person of the harbinger of Christ, that the Word, the light of truth, by becoming the Gospel, might break the mystic silence of the prophetic enigmas.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:96
verses.text: But if thou desirest truly to see God, take to thyself means of purification worthy of Him, not leaves of laurel fillets interwoven with wool and purple; but wreathing thy brows with righteousness, and encircling them with the leaves of temperance, set thyself earnestly to find Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:97
verses.text: "For I am," He says, "the door," which we who desire to understand God must discover, that He may throw heaven's gates wide open to us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:98
verses.text: For the gates of the Word being intellectual, are opened by the key of faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:99
verses.text: No one knows God but the Son, and he to whom the Son shall reveal Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 1:100
verses.text: And I know well that He who has opened the door hitherto shut, will afterwards reveal what is within; and will show what we could not have known before, had we not entered in by Christ, through whom alone God is beheld.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 2—The Absurdity and Impiety of the Heathen Mysteries and Fables About the Birth and Death of Their Gods.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:2
verses.text: Explore not then too curiously the shrines of impiety, or the mouths of caverns full of monstrosity, or the Thesprotian caldron, or the Cirrhaean tripod, or the Dodonian copper.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:3
verses.text: The Gerandryon, once regarded sacred in the midst of desert sands, and the oracle there gone to decay with the oak itself, consigned to the region of antiquated fables.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:4
verses.text: The fountain of Castalia is silent, and the other fountain of Colophon; and, in like manner, all the rest of the springs of divination are dead, and stripped of their vainglory, although at a late date, are shown with their fabulous legends to have run dry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:5
verses.text: Recount to us also the useless oracles of that other kind of divination, or rather madness, the Clarian, the Pythian, the Didymaean, that of Amphiaraus, of Apollo, of Amphilochus; and if you will, couple  with them the expounders of prodigies, the augurs, and the interpreters of dreams.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:6
verses.text: And bring and place beside the Pythian those that divine by flour, and those that divine by barley, and the ventriloquists still held in honour by many.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:7
verses.text: Let the secret shrines of the Egyptians and the necromancies of the Etruscans be consigned to darkness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:8
verses.text: Insane devices truly are they all of unbelieving men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:9
verses.text: Goats, too, have been confederates in this art of soothsaying, trained to divination; and crows taught by men to give oracular responses to men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:10
verses.text: And what if I go over the mysteries? I will not divulge them in mockery, as they say Alcibiades did, but I will expose right well by the word of truth the sorcery hidden in them; and those so-called gods of yours, whose are the mystic rites, I shall display, as it were, on the stage of life, to the spectators of truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:11
verses.text: The bacchanals hold their orgies in honour of the frenzied Dionysus, celebrating their sacred frenzy by the eating of raw flesh, and go through the distribution of the parts of butchered victims, crowned with snakes, shrieking out the name of that Eva by whom error came into the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:12
verses.text: The symbol of the Bacchic orgies is a consecrated serpent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:13
verses.text: Moreover, according to the strict interpretation of the Hebrew term, the name Hevia, aspirated, signifies a female serpent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:14
verses.text: Demeter and Proserpine have become the heroines of a mystic drama; and their wanderings, and seizure, and grief, Eleusis celebrates by torchlight processions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:15
verses.text: I think that the derivation of orgies and mysteries ought to be traced, the former to the wrath (ὀργή) of Demeter against Zeus, the latter to the nefarious wickedness (μύσος) relating to Dionysus; but if from Myus of Attica, who Pollodorus says was killed in hunting—no matter, I don't grudge your mysteries the glory of funeral honours.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:16
verses.text: You may understand mysteria in another way, as mytheria (hunting fables), the letters of the two words being interchanged; for certainly fables of this sort hunt after the most barbarous of the Thracians, the most senseless of the Phrygians, and the superstitious among the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:17
verses.text: Perish, then, the man who was the author of this imposture among men, be he Dardanus, who taught the mysteries of the mother of the gods, or Eetion, who instituted the orgies and mysteries of the Samothracians, or that Phrygian Midas who, having learned the cunning imposture from Odrysus, communicated it to his subjects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:18
verses.text: For I will never be persuaded by that Cyprian Islander Cinyras, who dared to bring forth from night to the light of day the lewd orgies of Aphrodité in his eagerness to deify a strumpet of his own country.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:19
verses.text: Others say that Melampus the son of Amythaon imported the festivals of Ceres from Egypt into Greece, celebrating her grief in song.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:20
verses.text: These I would instance as the prime authors of evil, the parents of impious fables and of deadly superstition, who sowed in human life that seed of evil and ruin—the mysteries.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:21
verses.text: And now, for it is time, I will prove their orgies to be full of imposture and quackery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:22
verses.text: And if you have been initiated, you will laugh all the more at these fables of yours which have been held in honour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:23
verses.text: I publish without reserve what has been involved in secrecy, not ashamed to tell what you are not ashamed to worship.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:24
verses.text: There is then the foam-born and Cyprus-born, the darling of Cinyras,—I mean Aphrodité, lover of the virilia, because sprung from them, even from those of Uranus, that were cut off,—those lustful members, that, after being cut off, offered violence to the waves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:25
verses.text: Of members so lewd a worthy fruit—Aphrodité—is born.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:26
verses.text: In the rites which celebrate this enjoyment of the sea, as a symbol of her birth a lump of salt and the phallus are handed to those who are initiated into the art of uncleanness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:27
verses.text: And those initiated bring a piece of money to her, as a courtesan's paramours do to her.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:28
verses.text: Then there are the mysteries of Demeter, and Zeus's wanton embraces of his mother, and the wrath of Demeter; I know not what for the future I shall call her, mother or wife, on which account it is that she is called Brimo, as is said; also the entreaties of Zeus, and the drink of gall, the plucking out of the hearts of sacrifices, and deeds that we dare not name.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:29
verses.text: Such rites the Phrygians perform in honour of Attis and Cybele and the Corybantes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:30
verses.text: And the story goes, that Zeus, having torn away the orchites of a ram, brought them out and cast them at the breasts of Demeter, paying thus a fraudulent penalty for his violent embrace, pretending to have cut out his own.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:31
verses.text: The symbols of initiation into these rites, when set before you in a vacant hour, I know will excite your laughter, although on account of the exposure by no means inclined to laugh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:32
verses.text: "I have eaten out of the drum, I have drunk out of the cymbal, I have carried the Cernos, I have slipped into the bedroom".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:33
verses.text: Are not these tokens a disgrace? Are not the mysteries absurdity?  What if I add the rest? Demeter becomes a mother, Core is reared up to womanhood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:34
verses.text: And, in course of time, he who begot her,—this same Zeus has intercourse with his own daughter Pherephatta,—after Ceres, the mother,—forgetting his former abominable wickedness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:35
verses.text: Zeus is both the father and the seducer of Core,  and shamefully courts her in the shape of a dragon; his identity, however, was discovered.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:36
verses.text: The token of the Sabazian mysteries to the initiated is "the deity gliding over the breast,"—the deity being this serpent crawling over the breasts of the initiated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:37
verses.text: Proof surely this of the unbridled lust of Zeus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:38
verses.text: Pherephatta has a child, though, to be sure, in the form of a bull, as an idolatrous poet says,—  "The bull The dragon's father, and the father of the bull the dragon, On a hill the herdsman's hidden ox-goad,"—  alluding, as I believe, under the name of the herdsman's ox-goad, to the reed wielded by bacchanals.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:39
verses.text: Do you wish me to go into the story of Persephatta's gathering of flowers, her basket, and her seizure by Pluto (Aidoneus), and the rent in the earth, and the swine of Eubouleus that were swallowed up with the two goddesses; for which reason, in the Thesmophoria, speaking the Megaric tongue, they thrust out swine? This mythological story the women celebrate variously in different cities in the festivals called Thesmophoria and Scirophoria; dramatizing in many forms the rape of Pherephatta or Persephatta (Proserpine).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:40
verses.text: The mysteries of Dionysus are wholly inhuman; for while still a child, and the Curetes danced around his cradle clashing their weapons, and the Titans having come upon them by stealth, and having beguiled him with childish toys, these very Titans tore him limb from limb when but a child, as the bard of this mystery, the Thracian Orpheus, says:—  "Cone, and spinning-top, and limb-moving rattles, And fair golden apples from the clear-toned Hesperides".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:41
verses.text: And the useless symbols of this mystic rite it will not be useless to exhibit for condemnation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:42
verses.text: These are dice, ball, hoop, apples, top, looking-glass, tuft of wool.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:43
verses.text: Athené (Minerva), to resume our account, having abstracted the heart of Dionysus, was called Pallas, from the vibrating of the heart; and the Titans who had torn him limb from limb, setting a caldron on a tripod, and throwing into it the members of Dionysus, first boiled them down, and then fixing them on spits, "held them over the fire".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:44
verses.text: But Zeus having appeared, since he was a god, having speedily perceived the savour of the pieces of flesh that were being cooked,—that savour which your gods agree to have assigned to them as their perquisite,—assails the Titans with his thunderbolt, and consigns the members of Dionysus to his son Apollo to be interred.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:45
verses.text: And he—for he did not disobey Zeus—bore the dismembered corpse to Parnassus, and there deposited it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:46
verses.text: If you wish to inspect the orgies of the Corybantes, then know that, having killed their third brother, they covered the head of the dead body with a purple cloth, crowned it, and carrying it on the point of a spear, buried it under the roots of Olympus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:47
verses.text: These mysteries are, in short, murders and funerals.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:48
verses.text: And the priests of these rites, who are called kings of the sacred rites by those whose business it is to name them, give additional strangeness to the tragic occurrence, by forbidding parsley with the roots from being placed on the table, for they think that parsley grew from the Corybantic blood that flowed forth; just as the women, in celebrating the Thesmophoria, abstain from eating the seeds of the pomegranate which have fallen on the ground, from the idea that pomegranates sprang from the drops of the blood of Dionysus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:49
verses.text: Those Corybantes also they call Cabiric; and the ceremony itself they announce as the Cabiric mystery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:50
verses.text: For those two identical fratricides, having abstracted the box in which the phallus of Bacchus was deposited, took it to Etruria—dealers in honourable wares truly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:51
verses.text: They lived there as exiles, employing themselves in communicating the precious teaching of their superstition, and presenting phallic symbols and the box for the Tyrrhenians to worship.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:52
verses.text: And some will have it, not improbably, that for this reason Dionysus was called Attis, because he was mutilated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:53
verses.text: And what is surprising at the Tyrrhenians, who were barbarians, being thus initiated into these foul indignities, when among the Athenians, and in the whole of Greece—I blush to say it—the shameful legend about Demeter holds its ground? For Demeter, wandering in quest of her daughter Core, broke down with fatigue near Eleusis, a place in Attica, and sat down on a well overwhelmed with grief.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:54
verses.text: This is even now prohibited to those who are initiated, lest they should appear to mimic the weeping goddess.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:55
verses.text: The indigenous inhabitants then occupied Eleusis: their names were Baubo, and Dusaules, and Triptolemus; and besides, Eumolpus and Eubouleus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:56
verses.text: Triptolemus was a herdsman, Eumolpus a shepherd, and Eubouleus a swineherd; from whom came the race of the Eumolpidae and that of the Heralds—a race of Hierophants—who flourished at Athens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:57
verses.text: Well, then (for I shall not refrain from the recital), Baubo having received Demeter hospitably, reaches to her a refreshing draught; and on her refusing it, not having any inclination to drink (for she was very sad), and Baubo having become annoyed, thinking herself slighted, uncovered her shame, and exhibited her nudity to the goddess.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:58
verses.text: Demeter is delighted at the sight, and takes, though with difficulty, the draught—pleased,  I repeat, at the spectacle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:59
verses.text: These are the secret mysteries of the Athenians; these Orpheus records.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:60
verses.text: I shall produce the very words of Orpheus, that you may have the great authority on the mysteries himself, as evidence for this piece of turpitude:—  "Having thus spoken, she drew aside her garments, And showed all that shape of the body which it is improper to name, And with her own hand Baubo stripped herself under the breasts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:61
verses.text: Blandly then the goddess laughed and laughed in her mind, And received the glancing cup in which was the draught".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:62
verses.text: And the following is the token of the Eleusinian mysteries: I have fasted, I have drunk the cup; I have received from the box; having done, I put it into the basket, and out of the basket into the chest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:63
verses.text: Fine sights truly, and becoming a goddess; mysteries worthy of the night, and flame, and the magnanimous or rather silly people of the Erechthidae and the other Greeks besides, "whom a fate they hope not for awaits after death".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:64
verses.text: And in truth against these Heraclitus the Ephesian prophesies, as "the night-walkers, the magi, the bacchanals, the Lenaen revellers, the initiated".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:65
verses.text: These he threatens with what will follow death, and predicts for them fire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:66
verses.text: For what are regarded among men as mysteries, they celebrate sacrilegiously.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:67
verses.text: Law, then, and opinion, are nugatory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:68
verses.text: And the mysteries of the dragon are an imposture, which celebrates religiously mysteries that are no mysteries at all, and observes with a spurious piety profane rites.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:69
verses.text: What are these mystic chests?—for I must expose their sacred things, and divulge things not fit for speech.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:70
verses.text: Are they not sesame cakes, and pyramidal cakes, and globular and flat cakes, embossed all over, and lumps of salt, and a serpent the symbol of Dionysus Bassareus? And besides these, are they not pomegranates, and branches, and rods, and ivy leaves? and besides, round cakes and poppy seeds? And further, there are the unmentionable symbols of Themis, marjoram, a lamp, a sword, a woman's comb, which is a euphemism and mystic expression for the muliebria.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:71
verses.text: O unblushing shamelessness! Once on a time night was silent, a veil for the pleasure of temperate men; but now for the initiated, the holy night is the tell-tale of the rites of licentiousness; and the glare of torches reveals vicious indulgences.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:72
verses.text: Quench the flame, O Hierophant; reverence, O Torch-bearer, the torches.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:73
verses.text: That light exposes Iacchus; let thy mysteries be honoured, and command the orgies to be hidden in night and darkness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:74
verses.text: The fire dissembles not; it exposes and punishes what it is bidden.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:75
verses.text: Such are the mysteries of the Atheists.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:76
verses.text: And with reason I call those Atheists who know not the true God, and pay shameless worship to a boy torn in pieces by the Titans, and a woman in distress, and to parts of the body that in truth cannot be mentioned for shame, held fast as they are in the double impiety, first in that they know not God, not acknowledging as God Him who truly is; the other and second is the error of regarding those who exist not, as existing and calling those gods that have no real existence, or rather no existence at all, who have nothing but a name.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:77
verses.text: Wherefore the apostle reproves us, saying, "And ye were strangers to the covenants of promise, having no hope, and without God in the world".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:78
verses.text: All honour to that king of the Scythians, whoever Anacharsis was, who shot with an arrow one of his subjects who imitated among the Scythians the mystery of the Mother of the gods, as practiced by the inhabitants of Cyzicus, beating a drum and sounding a cymbal strung from his neck like a priest of Cybele, condemning him as having become effeminate among the Greeks, and a teacher of the disease of effeminacy to the rest of the Cythians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:79
verses.text: Wherefore (for I must by no means conceal it) I cannot help wondering how Euhemerus of Agrigentum, and Nicanor of Cyprus, and Diagoras, and Hippo of Melos, and besides these, that Cyrenian of the name of Theodorus, and numbers of others, who lived a sober life, and had a clearer insight than the rest of the world into the prevailing error respecting those gods, were called Atheists; for if they did not arrive at the knowledge of the truth, they certainly suspected the error of the common opinion; which suspicion is no insignificant seed, and becomes the germ of true wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:80
verses.text: One of these charges the Egyptians thus: "If you believe them to be gods, do not mourn or bewail them; and if you mourn and bewail them, do not any more regard them as gods".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:81
verses.text: And another, taking an image of Hercules made of wood (for he happened most likely to be cooking something at home), said, "Come now, Hercules; now is the time to undergo for us this thirteenth labour, as you did the twelve for Eurystheus, and make this ready for Diagoras," and so cast it into the fire as a log of wood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:82
verses.text: For the extremes of ignorance are atheism and superstition, from which we must endeavour to keep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:83
verses.text: And do you not see Moses, the hierophant of the truth, enjoining that no eunuch, or emasculated man, or son of a harlot, should enter the congregation? By the two first  he alludes to the impious custom by which men were deprived both of divine energy and of their virility; and by the third, to him who, in place of the only real God, assumes many gods falsely so called,—as the son of a harlot, in ignorance of his true father, may claim many putative fathers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:84
verses.text: There was an innate original communion between men and heaven, obscured through ignorance, but which now at length has leapt forth instantaneously from the darkness, and shines resplendent; as has been expressed by one in the following lines:—  "See'st thou this lofty, this boundless ether, Holding the earth in the embrace of its humid arms".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:85
verses.text: And in these:—  "O Thou, who makest the earth Thy chariot, and in the earth hast Thy seat, Whoever Thou be, baffling our efforts to behold Thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:86
verses.text: And whatever else the sons of the poets sing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:87
verses.text: But sentiments erroneous, and deviating from what is right, and certainly pernicious, have turned man, a creature of heavenly origin, away from the heavenly life, and stretched him on the earth, by inducing him to cleave to earthly objects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:88
verses.text: For some, beguiled by the contemplation of the heavens, and trusting to their sight alone, while they looked on the motions of the stars, straightway were seized with admiration, and deified them, calling the stars gods from their motion (θεός from θεῖν); and worshipped the sun,—as, for example, the Indians; and the moon, as the Phrygians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:89
verses.text: Others, plucking the benignant fruits of earth-born plants, called grain Demeter, as the Athenians, and the vine Dionysus, as the Thebans.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:90
verses.text: Others, considering the penalties of wickedness, deified them, worshipping various forms of retribution and calamity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:91
verses.text: Hence the Erinnyes, and the Eumenides, and the piacular deities, and the judges and avengers of crime, are the creations of the tragic poets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:92
verses.text: And some even of the philosophers, after the poets, make idols of forms of the affections in your breasts,—such as fear, and love, and joy, and hope; as, to be sure, Epimenides of old, who raised at Athens the altars of Insult and Impudence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:93
verses.text: Other objects deified by men take their rise from events, and are fashioned in bodily shape, such as a Dike, a Clotho, and Lachesis, and Atropos, and Heimarmene, and Auxo, and Thallo, which are Attic goddesses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:94
verses.text: There is a sixth mode of introducing error and of manufacturing gods, according to which they number the twelve gods, whose birth is the theme of which Hesiod sings in his Theogony, and of whom Homer speaks in all that he says of the gods.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:95
verses.text: The last mode remains (for there are seven in all)—that which takes its rise from the divine beneficence towards men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:96
verses.text: For, not understanding that it is God that does us good, they have invented saviours in the persons of the Dioscuri, and Hercules the averter of evil, and Asclepius the healer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:97
verses.text: These are the slippery and hurtful deviations from the truth which draw man down from heaven, and cast him into the abyss.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:98
verses.text: I wish to show thoroughly what like these gods of yours are, that now at length you may abandon your delusion, and speed your flight back to heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:99
verses.text: "For we also were once children of wrath, even as others; but God, being rich in mercy, for the great love wherewith He loved us, when we were now dead in trespasses, quickened us together with Christ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:100
verses.text: For the Word is living, and having been buried with Christ, is exalted with God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:101
verses.text: But those who are still unbelieving are called children of wrath, reared for wrath.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:102
verses.text: We who have been rescued from error, and restored to the truth, are no longer the nurslings of wrath.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:103
verses.text: Thus, therefore, we who were once the children of lawlessness, have through the philanthropy of the Word now become the sons of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:104
verses.text: But to you a poet of your own, Empedocles of Agrigentum, comes and says:—  "Wherefore, distracted with grievous evils, You will never ease your soul of its miserable woes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:105
verses.text: The most of what is told of your gods is fabled and invented; and those things which are supposed to have taken place, are recorded of vile men who lived licentious lives:—  "You walk in pride and madness, And leaving the right and straight path, you have gone away Through thorns and briars.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:106
verses.text: Why do ye wander? Cease, foolish men, from mortals; Leave the darkness of night, and lay hold on the light".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:107
verses.text: These counsels the Sibyl, who is at once prophetic and poetic, enjoins on us; and truth enjoins them on us too, stripping the crowd of deities of those terrifying and threatening masks of theirs, disproving the rash opinions formed of them by showing the similarity of names.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:108
verses.text: For there are those who reckon three Jupiters: him of aether in Arcadia, and the other two sons of Kronos; and of these, one in Crete, and the others again in Arcadia.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:109
verses.text: And there are those that reckon five Athenes: the Athenian, the daughter of Hephaestus; the second, the Egyptian, the daughter of Nilus; the third the inventor of war, the daughter of Kronos; the fourth, the daughter of Zeus, whom the Messenians have named Coryphasia, from her mother; above all, the daughter of Pallas and Titanis, the daughter of Oceanus, who, having wickedly killed her father, adorned  herself with her father's skin, as if it had been the fleece of a sheep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:110
verses.text: Further, Aristotle calls the first Apollo, the son of Hephaestus and Athene (consequently Athene is no more a virgin); the second, that in Crete, the son of Corybas; the third, the son Zeus; the fourth, the Arcadian, the son of Silenus (this one is called by the Arcadians Nomius); and in addition to these, he specifies the Libyan Apollo, the son of Ammon; and to these Didymus the grammarian adds a sixth, the son of Magnes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:111
verses.text: And now how many Apollos are there? They are numberless, mortal men, all helpers of their fellow-men who similarly with those already mentioned have been so called.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:112
verses.text: And what were I to mention the many Asclepiuses, or all the Mercuries that are reckoned up, or the Vulcans of fable? Shall I not appear extravagant, deluging your ears with these numerous names?  At any rate, the native countries of your gods, and their arts and lives, and besides especially their sepulchres, demonstrate them to have been men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:113
verses.text: Mars, accordingly, who by the poets is held in the highest possible honour:—  "Mars, Mars, bane of men, blood-stained stormer of walls,"—  this deity, always changing sides, and implacable, as Epicharmus says, was a Spartan; Sophocles knew him for a Thracian; others say he was an Arcadian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:114
verses.text: This god, Homer says, was bound thirteen months:—  "Mars had his suffering; by Alöeus' sons, Otus and Ephialtes, strongly bound, He thirteen months in brazen fetters lay".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:115
verses.text: Good luck attend the Carians, who sacrifice dogs to him! And may the Scythians never leave off sacrificing asses, as Apollodorus and Callimachus relate:—  "Phoebus rises propitious to the Hyperboreans, Then they offer sacrifices of asses to him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:116
verses.text: And the same in another place:—  "Fat sacrifices of asses' flesh delight Phoebus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:117
verses.text: Hephaestus, whom Jupiter cast from Olympus, from its divine threshold, having fallen on Lemnos, practiced the art of working in brass, maimed in his feet:—  "His tottering knees were bowed beneath his weight".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:118
verses.text: You have also a doctor, and not only a brass-worker among the gods.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:119
verses.text: And the doctor was greedy of gold; Asclepius was his name.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:120
verses.text: I shall produce as a witness your own poet, the Boeotian Pindar:—  "Him even the gold glittering in his hands, Amounting to a splendid fee, persuaded To rescue a man, already death's capture, from his grasp; But Saturnian Jove, having shot his bolt through both, Quickly took the breath from their breasts, And his flaming thunderbolt sealed their doom".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:121
verses.text: And Euripides:—  "For Zeus was guilty of the murder of my son Asclepius, by casting the lightning flame at his breast".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:122
verses.text: He therefore lies struck with lightning in the regions of Cynosuris.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:123
verses.text: Philochorus also says, that Poseidon was worshipped as a physician in Tenos; and that Kronos settled in Sicily, and there was buried.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:124
verses.text: Patroclus the Thurian, and Sophocles the younger, in three tragedies, have told the story of the Dioscuri; and these Dioscuri were only two mortals, if Homer is worthy of of credit:—  ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:125
verses.text: but they beneath the teeming earth, In Lacedaemon lay, their native land".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:126
verses.text: And, in addition, he who wrote the Cyprian poems says Castor was mortal, and death was decreed to him by fate; but Pollux was immortal, being the progeny of Mars.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:127
verses.text: This he has poetically fabled.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:128
verses.text: But Homer is more worthy of credit, who spoke as above of both the Dioscuri; and, besides, proved Herucles to be a mere phantom:—  "The man Hercules, expert in mighty deeds".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:129
verses.text: Hercules, therefore, was known by Homer himself as only a mortal man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:130
verses.text: And Hieronymus the philosopher describes the make of his body, as tall, bristling-haired, robust; and Dicaerchus says that he was square-built, muscular, dark, hook-nosed, with greyish eyes and long hair.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:131
verses.text: This Hercules, accordingly, after living fifty-two years, came to his end, and was burned in a funeral pyre in oeta.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:132
verses.text: As for the Muses, whom Alcander calls the daughters of Zeus and Mnemosyne, and the rest of the poets and authors deify and worship,—those Muses, in honour of whom whole states have already erected museums, being handmaids, were hired by Megaclo, the daughter of Macar.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:133
verses.text: This Macar reigned over the Lesbians, and was always quarrelling with his wife; and Megaclo was vexed for her mother's sake.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:134
verses.text: What would she not do on her account? Accordingly she hires those handmaids, being so many in number, and calls them Mysae, according to the dialect of the aeolians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:135
verses.text: These she taught to sing deeds of the olden time, and play melodiously on the lyre.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:136
verses.text: And they, by assiduously playing the lyre, and singing sweetly to it, soothed Macar, and put a stop to his ill-temper.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:137
verses.text: Wherefore Megaclo, as a token of gratitude to them, on her mother's account erected brazen pillars, and ordered them to be held in honour in all the temples.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:138
verses.text: Such, then, are the Muses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:139
verses.text: This account is in Myrsilus of Lesbos.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:140
verses.text: And now, then, hear the loves of your gods, and the incredible tales of their licentiousness, and their wounds, and their bonds, and their laughings, and their fights, their servitudes too, and their banquets; and furthermore, their embraces, and tears, and sufferings, and lewd delights.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:141
verses.text: Call me Poseidon, and the troop of damsels deflowered by him, Amphitrite, Amymone, Alope, Melanippe, Alcyone, Hippothoe, Chione, and myriads of others; with whom, though so many, the passions of your Poseidon were not satiated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:142
verses.text: Call me Apollo; this is Phoebus, both a holy prophet and a good adviser.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:143
verses.text: But Sterope will not say that, nor aethousa, nor Arsinoe, nor Zeuxippe, nor Prothoe, nor Marpissa, nor Hypsipyle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:144
verses.text: For Daphne alone escaped the prophet and seduction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:145
verses.text: And, above all, let the father of gods and men, according to you, himself come, who was so given to sexual pleasure, as to lust after all, and indulge his lust on all, like the goats of the Thmuitae.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:146
verses.text: And thy poems, O Homer, fill me with admiration!  "He said, and nodded with his shadowy brows; Waved on the immortal head the ambrosial locks, And all Olympus trembled at his nod".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:147
verses.text: Thou makest Zeus venerable, O Homer; and the nod which thou dost ascribe to him is most reverend.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:148
verses.text: But show him only a woman's girdle, and Zeus is exposed, and his locks are dishonoured.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:149
verses.text: To what a pitch of licentiousness did that Zeus of yours proceed, who spent so many nights in voluptuousness with Alcmene? For not even these nine nights were long to this insatiable monster.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:150
verses.text: But, on the contrary, a whole lifetime were short enough for his lust; that he might beget for us the evil-averting god.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:151
verses.text: Hercules, the son of Zeus—a true son of Zeus—was the offspring of that long night, who with hard toil accomplished the twelve labours in a long time, but in one night deflowered the fifty daughters of Thestius, and thus was at once the debaucher and the bridegroom of so many virgins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:152
verses.text: It is not, then, without reason that the poets call him a cruel wretch and a nefarious scoundrel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:153
verses.text: It were tedious to recount his adulteries of all sorts, and debauching of boys.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:154
verses.text: For your gods did not even abstain from boys, one having loved Hylas, another Hyacinthus, another Pelops, another Chrysippus, and another Ganymede.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:155
verses.text: Let such gods as these be worshipped by your wives, and let them pray that their husbands be such as these—so temperate; that, emulating them in the same practices, they may be like the gods.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:156
verses.text: Such gods let your boys be trained to worship, that they may grow up to be men with the accursed likeness of fornication on them received from the gods.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:157
verses.text: But it is only the male deities, perhaps, that are impetuous in sexual indulgence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:158
verses.text: "The female deities stayed each in the house, for shame," says Homer; the goddesses blushing, for modesty's sake, to look on Aphrodité when she had been guilty of adultery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:159
verses.text: But these are more passionately licentious, bound in the chains of adultery; Eos having disgraced herself with Tithonus, Selene with Endymion, Nereis with aeacus, Thetis with Peleus, Demeter with Jason, Persephatta with Adonis.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:160
verses.text: And Aphrodité having disgraced herself with Ares, crossed over to Cinyra and married Anchises, and laid snares for Phaëthon, and loved Adonis.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:161
verses.text: She contended with the ox-eyed Juno; and the goddesses un-robed for the sake of the apple, and presented themselves naked before the shepherd, that he might decide which was the fairest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:162
verses.text: But come, let us briefly go the round of the games, and do away with those solemn assemblages at tombs, the Isthmian, Nemean, and Pythian, and finally the Olympian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:163
verses.text: At Pytho the Pythian dragon is worshipped, and the festival-assemblage of the serpent is called by the name Pythia.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:164
verses.text: At the Isthmus the sea spit out a piece of miserable refuse; and the Isthmian games bewail Melicerta.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:165
verses.text: At Nemea another—a little boy, Archemorus—was buried; and the funeral games of the child are called Nemea.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:166
verses.text: Pisa is the grave of the Phrygian charioteer, O Hellenes of all tribes; and the Olympian games, which are nothing else than the funeral sacrifices of Pelops, the Zeus of Phidias claims for himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:167
verses.text: The mysteries were then, as is probable, games held in honour of the dead; so also were the oracles, and both became public.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:168
verses.text: But the mysteries at Sagra and in Alimus of Attica were confined to Athens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:169
verses.text: But those contests and phalloi consecrated to Dionysus were a world's shame, pervading life with their deadly influence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:170
verses.text: For Dionysus, eagerly desiring to descend to Hades, did not know the way; a man, by name Prosymnus, offers to tell him, not without reward.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:171
verses.text: The reward was a disgraceful one, though not so in the opinion of Dionysus: it was an Aphrodisian favour that was asked of Dionysus as a reward.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:172
verses.text: The god was not reluctant to grant the request made to him, and promises to fulfil it should he return, and confirms his promise with an oath.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:173
verses.text: Having learned the way, he departed and again returned: he did not find Prosymnus, for he had died.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:174
verses.text: In order to acquit himself of his promise to his lover, he rushes to his tomb, and burns with unnatural lust.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:175
verses.text: Cutting a fig-branch that came to his hand, he shaped the phallus, and so performed his promise to the dead man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:176
verses.text: As a mystic memorial of this incident, phalloi are  raised aloft in honour of Dionysus through the various cities.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:177
verses.text: "For did they not make a procession in honour of Dionysus, and sing most shameless songs in honour of the pudenda, all would go wrong," says Heraclitus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:178
verses.text: This is that Pluto and Dionysus in whose honour they give themselves up to frenzy, and play the bacchanal,—not so much, in my opinion, for the sake of intoxication, as for the sake of the shameless ceremonial practiced.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:179
verses.text: With reason, therefore, such as have become slaves of their passions are your gods!  Furthermore, like the Helots among the Lacedemonians, Apollo came under the yoke of slavery to Admetus in Pherae, Hercules to Omphale in Sardis.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:180
verses.text: Poseidon was a drudge to Laomedon; and so was Apollo, who, like a good-for-nothing servant, was unable to obtain his freedom from his former master; and at that time the walls of Troy were built by them for the Phrygian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:181
verses.text: And Homer is not ashamed to speak of Athene as appearing to Ulysses with a golden lamp in her hand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:182
verses.text: And we read of Aphrodite, like a wanton serving-wench, taking and setting a seat for Helen opposite the adulterer, in order to entice him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:183
verses.text: Panyasis, too, tells us of gods in plenty besides those who acted as servants, writing thus:—  "Demeter underwent servitude, and so did the famous lame god; Poseidon underwent it, and Apollo too, of the silver bow, With a mortal man for a year.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:184
verses.text: And fierce Mars Underwent it at the compulsion of his father".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:185
verses.text: And so on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:186
verses.text: Agreeably to this, it remains for me to bring before you those amatory and sensuous deities of yours, as in every respect having human feelings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:187
verses.text: "For theirs was a mortal body".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:188
verses.text: This Homer most distinctly shows, by introducing Aphrodite uttering loud and shrill cries on account of her wound; and describing the most warlike Ares himself as wounded in the stomach by Diomede.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:189
verses.text: Polemo, too, says that Athene was wounded by Ornytus; nay, Homer says that Pluto even was struck with an arrow by Hercules; and Panyasis relates that the beams of Sol were struck by the arrows of Hercules; and the same Panyasis relates, that by the same Hercules Hera the goddess of marriage was wounded in sandy Pylos.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:190
verses.text: Sosibius, too, relates that Hercules was wounded in the hand by the sons of Hippocoon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:191
verses.text: And if there are wounds, there is blood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:192
verses.text: For the ichor of the poets is more repulsive than blood; for the putrefaction of blood is called ichor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:193
verses.text: Wherefore cures and means of sustenance of which they stand in need must be furnished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:194
verses.text: Accordingly mention is made of tables, and potations, and laughter, and intercourse; for men would not devote themselves to love, or beget children, or sleep, if they were immortal, and had no wants, and never grew old.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:195
verses.text: Jupiter himself, when the guest of Lycaon the Arcadian, partook of a human table among the Ethiopians—a table rather inhuman and forbidden.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:196
verses.text: For he satiated himself with human flesh unwittingly; for the god did not know that Lycaon the Arcadian, his entertainer, had slain his son (his name was Nyctimus), and served him up cooked before Zeus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:197
verses.text: This is Jupiter the good, the prophetic, the patron of hospitality, the protector of suppliants, the benign, the author of omens, the avenger of wrongs; rather the unjust, the violater of right and of law, the impious, the inhuman, the violent, the seducer, the adulterer, the amatory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:198
verses.text: But perhaps when he was such he was a man; but now these fables seem to have grown old on our hands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:199
verses.text: Zeus is no longer a serpent, a swan, nor an eagle, nor a licentious man; the god no longer flies, nor loves boys, nor kisses, nor offers violence, although there are still many beautiful women, more comely than Leda, more blooming than Semele, and boys of better looks and manners than the Phrygian herdsman.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:200
verses.text: Where is now that eagle? where now that swan? where now is Zeus himself? He has grown old with his feathers; for as yet he does not repent of his amatory exploits, nor is he taught continence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:201
verses.text: The fable is exposed before you: Leda is dead, the swan is dead.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:202
verses.text: Seek your Jupiter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:203
verses.text: Ransack not heaven, but earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:204
verses.text: The Cretan, in whose country he was buried, will show him to you,—I mean Callimachus, in his hymns:—  "For thy tomb, O king, The Cretans fashioned!"  For Zeus is dead, be not distressed, as Leda is dead, and the swan, and the eagle, and the libertine, and the serpent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:205
verses.text: And now even the superstitious seem, although reluctantly, yet truly, to have come to understand their error respecting the Gods.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:206
verses.text: "For not from an ancient oak, nor from a rock, But from men, is thy descent".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:207
verses.text: But shortly after this, they will be found to be but oaks and stones.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:208
verses.text: One Agamemnon is said by Staphylus to be worshipped as a Jupiter in Sparta; and Phanocles, in his book of the Brave and Fair, relates that Agamemnon king of the Hellenes erected the temple of Argennian Aphrodite, in honour of Argennus his friend.
