verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:209
verses.text: An Artemis, named the Strangled, is worshipped by the Arcadians, as Callimachus says in his Book of Causes; and at Methymna another Artemis had divine honours paid her, viz.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:210
verses.text: , Artemis Condylitis.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:211
verses.text: There is also the temple of another Artemis—Artemis Podagra (or, the gout)—in Laconica, as Sosibius says.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:212
verses.text: Polemo tells of an image of a yawning Apollo; and again of another image, reverenced in Elis, of the guzzling Apollo.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:213
verses.text: Then the Eleans sacrifice to Zeus, the averter of flies; and the Romans sacrifice to Hercules, the averter of flies; and to Fever, and to Terror, whom also they reckon among the attendants of Hercules.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:214
verses.text: (I pass over the Argives, who worshipped Aphrodite, opener of graves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:215
verses.text: ) The Argives and Spartans reverence Artemis Chelytis, or the cougher, from κελύττειν, which in their speech signifies to cough.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:216
verses.text: Do you imagine from what source these details have been quoted? Only such as are furnished by yourselves are here adduced; and you do not seem to recognise your own writers, whom I call as witnesses against your unbelief.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:217
verses.text: Poor wretches that ye are, who have filled with unholy jesting the whole compass of your life—a life in reality devoid of life!  Is not Zeus the Baldhead worshipped in Argos; and another Zeus, the avenger, in Cyprus? Do not the Argives sacrifice to Aphrodite Peribaso (the protectress), and the Athenians to Aphrodite Hetaera (the courtesan), and the Syracusans to Aphrodite Kallipygos, whom Nicander has somewhere called Kalliglutos (with beautiful rump).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:218
verses.text: I pass over in silence just now Dionysus Choiropsales.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:219
verses.text: The Sicyonians reverence this deity, whom they have constituted the god of the muliebria—the patron of filthiness—and religiously honour as the author of licentiousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:220
verses.text: Such, then, are their gods; such are they also who make mockery of the gods, or rather mock and insult themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:221
verses.text: How much better are the Egyptians, who in their towns and villages pay divine honours to the irrational creatures, than the Greeks, who worship such gods as these?  For if they are beasts, they are not adulterous or libidinous, and seek pleasure in nothing that is contrary to nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:222
verses.text: And of what sort these deities are, what need is there further to say, as they have been already sufficiently exposed? Furthermore, the Egyptians whom I have now mentioned are divided in their objects of worship.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:223
verses.text: The Syenites worship the braize-fish; and the maiotes—this is another fish—is worshipped by those who inhabit Elephantine: the Oxyrinchites likewise worship a fish which takes its name from their country.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:224
verses.text: Again, the Heraclitopolites worship the ichneumon, the inhabitants of Sais and of Thebes a sheep, the Leucopolites a wolf, the Cynopolites a dog, the Memphites Apis, the Mendesians a goat.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:225
verses.text: And you, who are altogether better than the Egyptians (I shrink from saying worse), who never cease laughing every day of your lives at the Egyptians, what are some of you, too, with regard to brute beasts? For of your number the Thessalians pay divine homage to storks, in accordance with ancient custom; and the Thebans to weasels, for their assistance at the birth of Hercules.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:226
verses.text: And again, are not the Thessalians reported to worship ants, since they have learned that Zeus in the likeness of an ant had intercourse with Eurymedusa, the daughter of Cletor, and begot Myrmidon? Polemo, too, relates that the people who inhabit the Troad worship the mice of the country, which they call Sminthoi, because they gnawed the strings of their enemies' bows; and from those mice Apollo has received his epithet of Sminthian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:227
verses.text: Heraclides, in his work, Regarding the Building of Temples in Acarnania, says that, at the place where the promontory of Actium is, and the temple of Apollo of Actium, they offer to the flies the sacrifice of an ox.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:228
verses.text: Nor shall I forget the Samians: the Samians, as Euphorion says, reverence the sheep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:229
verses.text: Nor shall I forget the Syrians, who inhabit Phoenicia, of whom some revere doves, and others fishes, with as excessive veneration as the Eleans do Zeus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:230
verses.text: Well, then, since those you worship are not gods, it seems to me requisite to ascertain if those are really demons who are ranked, as you say, in this second order next to the gods.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:231
verses.text: For if the lickerish and impure are demons, indigenous demons who have obtained sacred honours may be discovered in crowds throughout your cities: Menedemus among the Cythnians; among the Tenians, Callistagoras; among the Delians, Anius; among the Laconians, Astrabacus; at Phalerus, a hero affixed to the prow of ships is worshipped; and the Pythian priestess enjoined the Plataeans to sacrifice to Androcrates and Democrates, and Cyclaeus and Leuco while the Median war was at its height.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:232
verses.text: Other demons in plenty may be brought to light by any one who can look about him a little.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:233
verses.text: "For thrice ten thousand are there in the all-nourishing earth Of demons immortal, the guardians of articulate-speaking men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:234
verses.text: Who these guardians are, do not grudge, O Boeotian, to tell.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:235
verses.text: Is it not clear that they are those we have mentioned, and those of more renown, the great demons, Apollo, Artemis, Leto, Demeter, Core, Pluto, Hercules, and Zeus himself?  But it is from running away that they guard us, O Ascraean, or perhaps it is from sinning, as forsooth they have never tried their hand at sin  themselves! In that case verily the proverb may fitly be uttered:—  "The father who took no admonition admonishes his son".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:236
verses.text: If these are our guardians, it is not because they have any ardour of kindly feeling towards us, but intent on your ruin, after the manner of flatterers, they prey on your substance, enticed by the smoke.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:237
verses.text: These demons themselves indeed confess their own gluttony, saying:—  "For with drink-offerings due, and fat of lambs, My altar still hath at their hands been fed; Such honour hath to us been ever paid".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 2:238
verses.text: What other speech would they utter, if indeed the gods of the Egyptians, such as cats and weasels, should receive the faculty of speech, than that Homeric and poetic one which proclaims their liking for savoury odours and cookery? Such are your demons and gods, and demigods, if there are any so called, as there are demi-asses (mules); for you have no want of terms to make up compound names of impiety.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 3—The Cruelty of the Sacrifices to the Gods.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:2
verses.text: Well, now, let us say in addition, what inhuman demons, and hostile to the human race, your gods were, not only delighting in the insanity of men, but gloating over human slaughter,—now in the armed contests for superiority in the stadia, and now in the numberless contests for renown in the wars providing for themselves the means of pleasure, that they might be able abundantly to satiate themselves with the murder of human beings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:3
verses.text: And now, like plagues invading cities and nations, they demanded cruel oblations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:4
verses.text: Thus, Aristomenes the Messenian slew three hundred human beings in honour of Ithometan Zeus, thinking that hecatombs of such a number and quality would give good omens; among whom was Theopompos, king of the Lacedemonians, a noble victim.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:5
verses.text: The Taurians, the people who inhabit the Tauric Chersonese, sacrifice to the Tauric Artemis forthwith whatever strangers they lay hands on on their coasts who have been east adrift on the sea.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:6
verses.text: These sacrifices Euripides represents in tragedies on the stage.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:7
verses.text: Monimus relates, in his treatise on marvels, that at Pella, in Thessaly, a man of Achaia was slain in sacrifice to Peleus and Chiron.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:8
verses.text: That the Lyctii, who are a Cretan race, slew men in sacrifice to Zeus, Anticlides shows in his Homeward Journeys; and that the Lesbians offered the like sacrifice to Dionysus, is said by Dosidas.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:9
verses.text: The Phocaeans also (for I will not pass over such as they are), Pythocles informs us in his third book, On Concord, offer a man as a burnt-sacrifice to the Taurian Artemis.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:10
verses.text: Erechtheus of Attica and Marius the Roman sacrificed their daughters,—the former to Pherephatta, as Demaratus mentions in his first book on Tragic Subjects; the latter to the evil-averting deities, as Dorotheus relates in his first book of Italian Affairs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:11
verses.text: Philanthropic, assuredly, the demons appear, from these examples; and how shall those who revere the demons not be correspondingly pious? The former are called by the fair name of saviours; and the latter ask for safety from those who plot against their safety, imagining that they sacrifice with good omens to them, and forget that they themselves are slaying men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:12
verses.text: For a murder does not become a sacrifice by being committed in a particular spot.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:13
verses.text: You are not to call it a sacred sacrifice, if one slays a man either at the altar or on the highway to Artemis or Zeus, any more than if he slew him for anger or covetousness,—other demons very like the former; but a sacrifice of this kind is murder and human butchery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:14
verses.text: Then why is it, O men, wisest of all creatures, that you avoid wild beasts, and get out of the way of the savage animals, if you fall in with a bear or lion?  ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:15
verses.text: As when some traveller spies, Coiled in his path upon the mountain side, A deadly snake, back he recoils in haste,— His limbs all trembling, and his cheek all pale,"  But though you perceive and understand demons to be deadly and wicked, plotters, haters of the human race, and destroyers, why do you not turn out of their way, or turn them out of yours? What truth can the wicked tell, or what good can they do any one?  I can then readily demonstrate that man is better than these gods of yours, who are but demons; and can show, for instance, that Cyrus and Solon were superior to oracular Apollo.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:16
verses.text: Your Phoebus was a lover of gifts, but not a lover of men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:17
verses.text: He betrayed his friend Croesus, and forgetting the reward he had got (so careful was he of his fame), led him across the Halys to the stake.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:18
verses.text: The demons love men in such a way as to bring them to the fire unquenchable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:19
verses.text: But O man, who lovest the human race better, and art truer than Apollo, pity him that is bound on the pyre.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:20
verses.text: Do thou, O Solon, declare truth; and thou, O Cyrus, command the fire to be extinguished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:21
verses.text: Be wise, then, at last, O Croesus, taught by suffering.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:22
verses.text: He whom you worship is an ingrate; he accepts your reward, and after taking the gold plays false.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:23
verses.text: "Look again to the end, O Solon".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:24
verses.text: It is not the demon, but the man that tells you this.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:25
verses.text: It is not ambiguous  oracles that Solon utters.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:26
verses.text: You shall easily take him up.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:27
verses.text: Nothing but true, O Barbarian, shall you find by proof this oracle to be, when you are placed on the pyre.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:28
verses.text: Whence I cannot help wondering, by what plausible reasons those who first went astray were impelled to preach superstition to men, when they exhorted them to worship wicked demons, whether it was Phoroneus or Merops, or whoever else that raised temples and altars to them; and besides, as is fabled, were the first to offer sacrifices to them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:29
verses.text: But, unquestionably, in succeeding ages men invented for themselves gods to worship.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:30
verses.text: It is beyond doubt that this Eros, who is said to be among the oldest of the gods, was worshipped by no one till Charmus took a little boy and raised an altar to him in Academia,—a thing more seemly than the lust he had gratified; and the lewdness of vice men called by the name of Eros, deifying thus unbridled lust.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:31
verses.text: The Athenians, again, knew not who Pan was till Philippides told them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:32
verses.text: Superstition, then, as was to be expected, having taken its rise thus, became the fountain of insensate wickedness; and not being subsequently checked, but having gone on augmenting and rushing along in full flood, it became the originator of many demons, and was displayed in sacrificing hecatombs, appointing solemn assemblies, setting up images, and building temples, which were in reality tombs: for I will not pass these over in silence, but make a thorough exposure of them, though called by the august name of temples; that is, the tombs which got the name of temples.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:33
verses.text: But do ye now at length quite give up your superstition, feeling ashamed to regard sepulchres with religious veneration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:34
verses.text: In the temple of Athene in Larissa, on the Acropolis, is the grave of Acrisius; and at Athens, on the Acropolis, is that of Cecrops, as Antiochus says in the ninth book of his Histories.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:35
verses.text: What of Erichthonius? was he not buried in the temple of Polias? And Immarus, the son of Eumolpus and Daira, were they not buried in the precincts of the Elusinium, which is under the Acropolis; and the daughters of Celeus, were they not interred in Eleusis? Why should I enumerate to you the wives of the Hyperboreans? They were called Hyperoche and Laodice; they were buried in the Artemisium in Delos, which is in the temple of the Delian Apollo.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:36
verses.text: Leandrius says that Clearchus was buried in Miletus, in the Didymaeum.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:37
verses.text: Following the Myndian Zeno, it were unsuitable in this connection to pass over the sepulchre of Leucophryne, who was buried in the temple of Artemis in Magnesia; or the altar of Apollo in Telmessus, which is reported to be the tomb of Telmisseus the seer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:38
verses.text: Further, Ptolemy the son of Agesarchus, in his first book about Philopator, says that Cinyras and the descendants of Cinyras were interred in the temple of Aphrodite in Paphos.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:39
verses.text: But all time would not be sufficient for me, were I to go over the tombs which are held sacred by you.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:40
verses.text: And if no shame for these audacious impieties steals over you, it comes to this, that you are completely dead, putting, as really you do, your trust in the dead.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 3:41
verses.text: "Poor wretches, what misery is this you suffer? Your heads are enveloped in the darkness of night".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 4—The Absurdity and Shamefulness of the Images by Which the Gods are Worshipped.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:2
verses.text: If, in addition, I take and set before you for inspection these very images, you will, as you go over them, find how truly silly is the custom in which you have been reared, of worshipping the senseless works of men's hands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:3
verses.text: Anciently, then, the Scythians worshipped their sabres, the Arabs stones, the Persians rivers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:4
verses.text: And some, belonging to other races still more ancient, set up blocks of wood in conspicuous situations, and erected pillars of stone, which were called Xoana, from the carving of the material of which they were made.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:5
verses.text: The image of Artemis in Icarus was doubtless unwrought wood, and that of the Cithaeronian Here was a felled tree-trunk; and that of the Samian Here, as aethlius says, was at first a plank, and was afterwards during the government of Proclus carved into human shape.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:6
verses.text: And when the Xoana began to be made in the likeness of men, they got the name of Brete,—a term derived from Brotos (man).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:7
verses.text: In Rome, the historian Varro says that in ancient times the Xoaron of Mars—the idol by which he was worshipped—was a spear, artists not having yet applied themselves to this specious pernicious art; but when art flourished, error increased.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:8
verses.text: That of stones and stocks—and, to speak briefly, of dead matter—you have made images of human form, by which you have produced a counterfeit of piety, and slandered the truth, is now as clear as can be; but such proof as the point may demand must not be declined.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:9
verses.text: That the statue of Zeus at Olympia, and that of Polias at Athens, were executed of gold and ivory by Phidias, is known by everybody; and that the image of Here in Samos was formed by the chisel of Euclides, Olympichus relates in his Samiaca.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:10
verses.text: Do not, then, entertain any doubt, that of the gods called at Athens venerable, Scopas made two of the stone called Lychnis, and Calos the one which they are reported to have had placed between them, as Polemon shows in the fourth of his books addressed to  Timaeus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:11
verses.text: Nor need you doubt respecting the images of Zeus and Apollo at Patara, in Lycia, which Phidias executed, as well as the lions that recline with them; and if, as some say, they were the work of Bryxis, I do not dispute,—you have in him another maker of images.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:12
verses.text: Whichever of these you like, write down.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:13
verses.text: Furthermore, the statues nine cubits in height of Poseidon and Amphitrite, worshipped in Tenos, are the work of Telesius the Athenian, as we are told by Philochorus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:14
verses.text: Demetrius, in the second book of his Argolics, writes of the image of Here in Tiryns, both that the material was pear-tree and the artist was Argus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:15
verses.text: Many, perhaps, may be surprised to learn that the Palladium which is called the Diopetes—that is, fallen from heaven—which Diomede and Ulysses are related to have carried off from Troy and deposited at Demophoon, was made of the bones of Pelops, as the Olympian Jove of other bones—those of the Indian wild beast.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:16
verses.text: I adduce as my authority Dionysius, who relates this in the fifth part of his Cycle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:17
verses.text: And Apellas, in the Delphics, says that there were two Palladia, and that both were fashioned by men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:18
verses.text: But that one may suppose that I have passed over them through ignorance, I shall add that the image of Dionysus Morychus at Athens was made of the stones called Phellata, and was the work of Simon the son of Eupalamus, as Polemo says in a letter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:19
verses.text: There were also two other sculptors of Crete, as I think: they were called Scyles and Dipoenus; and these executed the statues of the Dioscuri in Argos, and the image of Hercules in Tiryns, and the effigy of the Munychian Artemis in Sicyon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:20
verses.text: Why should I linger over these, when I can point out to you the great deity himself, and show you who he was,—whom indeed, conspicuously above all, we hear to have been considered worthy of veneration? Him they have dared to speak of as made without hands—I mean the Egyptian Serapis.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:21
verses.text: For some relate that he was sent as a present by the people of Sinope to Ptolemy Philadelphus, king of the Egyptians, who won their favour by sending them corn from Egypt when they were perishing with famine; and that this idol was an image of Pluto; and Ptolemy, having received the statue, placed it on the promontory which is now called Racotis; where the temple of Serapis was held in honour, and the sacred enclosure borders on the spot; and that Blistichis the courtesan having died in Canopus, Ptolemy had her conveyed there, and buried beneath the forementioned shrine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:22
verses.text: Others say that the Serapis was a Pontic idol, and was transported with solemn pomp to Alexandria.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:23
verses.text: Isidore alone says that it was brought from the Seleucians, near Antioch, who also had been visited with a dearth of corn, and had been fed by Ptolemy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:24
verses.text: But Athenodorns the son of Sandon, while wishing to make out the Serapis to be ancient, has somehow slipped into the mistake of proving it to be an image fashioned by human hands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:25
verses.text: He says that Sesostris the Egyptian king, having subjugated the most of the Hellenic races, on his return to Egypt brought a number of craftsmen with him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:26
verses.text: Accordingly he ordered a statue of Osiris, his ancestor, to be executed in sumptuous style; and the work was done by the artist Bryaxis, not the Athenian, but another of the same name, who employed in its execution a mixture of various materials.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:27
verses.text: For he had filings of gold, and silver, and lead, and in addition, tin; and of Egyptian stones not one was wanting, and there were fragments of sapphire, and hematite, and emerald, and topaz.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:28
verses.text: Having ground down and mixed together all these ingredients, he gave to the composition a blue colour, whence the darkish hue of the image; and having mixed the whole with the colouring matter that was left over from the funeral of Osiris and Apis, moulded the Serapis, the name of which points to its connection with sepulture and its construction from funeral materials, compounded as it is of Osiris and Apis, which together make Osirapis.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:29
verses.text: Another new deity was added to the number with great religious pomp in Egypt, and was near being so in Greece by the king of the Romans, who deified Antinous, whom he loved as Zeus loved Ganymede, and whose beauty was of a very rare order: for lust is not easily restrained, destitute as it is of fear; and men now observe the sacred nights of Antinous, the shameful character of which the lover who spent them with him knew well.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:30
verses.text: Why reckon him among the gods, who is honoured on account of uncleanness? And why do you command him to be lamented as a son? And why should you enlarge on his beauty? Beauty blighted by vice is loathsome.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:31
verses.text: Do not play the tyrant, O man, over beauty, nor offer foul insult to youth in its bloom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:32
verses.text: Keep beauty pure, that it may be truly fair.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:33
verses.text: Be king over beauty, not its tyrant.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:34
verses.text: Remain free, and then I shall acknowledge thy beauty, because thou hast kept its image pure: then will I worship that true beauty which is the archetype of all who are beautiful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:35
verses.text: Now the grave of the debauched boy is the temple and town of Antinous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:36
verses.text: For just as temples are held in reverence, so also are sepulchres, and pyramids, and mausoleums, and labyrinths, which are temples of the dead, as the others are sepulchres of the gods.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:37
verses.text: As teacher on this point, I shall produce to you the Sibyl prophetess:—  "Not the oracular lie of Phoebus, Whom silly men called God, and falsely termed Prophet; But the oracles of the great God, who was not made by men's hands, Like dumb idols of Sculptured stone".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:38
verses.text: She also predicts the ruin of the temple, foretelling that that of the Ephesian Artemis would be engulphed by earthquakes and rents in the ground, as follows:—  "Prostrate on the ground Ephesus shall wail, weeping by the shore, And seeking a temple that has no longer an inhabitant".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:39
verses.text: She says also that the temple of Isis and Serapis would be demolished and burned:—  "Isis, thrice-wretched goddess, thou shalt linger by the streams of the Nile; Solitary, frenzied, silent, on the sands of Acheron".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:40
verses.text: Then she proceeds:—  "And thou, Serapis, covered with a heap of white stones, Shalt lie a huge ruin in thrice-wretched Egypt".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:41
verses.text: But if you attend not to the prophetess, hear at least your own philosopher, the Ephesian Heraclitus, upbraiding images with their senselessness: "And to these images they pray, with the same result as if one were to talk to the walls of his house".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:42
verses.text: For are they not to be wondered at who worship stones, and place them before the doors, as if capable of activity? They worship Hermes as a god, and place Aguieus as a doorkeeper.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:43
verses.text: For if people upbraid them with being devoid of sensation, why worship them as gods? And if they are thought to be endowed with sensation, why place them before the door? The Romans, who ascribed their greatest successes to Fortune, and regarded her as a very great deity, took her statue to the privy, and erected it there, assigning to the goddess as a fitting temple—the necessary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:44
verses.text: But senseless wood and stone, and rich gold, care not a whit for either savoury odour, or blood, or smoke, by which, being at once honoured and fumigated, they are blackened; no more do they for honour or insult.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:45
verses.text: And these images are more worthless than any animal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:46
verses.text: I am at a loss to conceive how objects devoid of sense were deified, and feel compelled to pity as miserable wretches those that wander in the mazes of this folly: for if some living creatures have not all the senses, as worms and caterpillars, and such as even from the first appear imperfect, as moles and the shrew-mouse, which Nicander says is blind and uncouth; yet are they superior to those utterly senseless idols and images.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:47
verses.text: For they have some one sense,—say, for example, hearing, or touching, or something analogous to smell or taste; while images do not possess even one sense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:48
verses.text: There are many creatures that have neither sight, nor hearing, nor speech, such as the genus of oysters, which yet live and grow, and are affected by the changes of the moon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:49
verses.text: But images, being motionless, inert, and senseless, are bound, nailed, glued,—are melted, filed, sawed, polished, carved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:50
verses.text: The senseless earth is dishonoured by the makers of images, who change it by their art from its proper nature, and induce men to worship it; and the makers of gods worship not gods and demons, but in my view earth and art, which go to make up images.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:51
verses.text: For, in sooth, the image is only dead matter shaped by the craftsman's hand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:52
verses.text: But we have no sensible image of sensible matter, but an image that is perceived by the mind alone,—God, who alone is truly God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:53
verses.text: And again, when involved in calamities, the superstitious worshippers of stones, though they have learned by the event that senseless matter is not to be worshipped, yet, yielding to the pressure of misfortune, become the victims of their superstition; and though despising the images, yet not wishing to appear wholly to neglect them, are found fault with by those gods by whose names the images are called.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:54
verses.text: For Dionysius the tyrant, the younger, having stripped off the golden mantle from the statue of Jupiter in Sicily, ordered him to be clothed in a woollen one, remarking facetiously that the latter was better than the golden one, being lighter in summer and warmer in winter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:55
verses.text: And Antiochus of Cyzicus, being in difficulties for money, ordered the golden statue of Zeus, fifteen cubits in height, to be melted; and one like it, of less valuable material, plated with gold, to be erected in place of it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:56
verses.text: And the swallows and most birds fly to these statues, and void their excrement on them, paying no respect either to Olympian Zeus, or Epidaurian Asclepius, or even to Athene Polias, or the Egyptian Serapis; but not even from them have you learned the senselessness of images.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:57
verses.text: But it has happened that miscreants or enemies have assailed and set fire to temples, and plundered them of their votive gifts, and melted even the images themselves, from base greed of gain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:58
verses.text: And if a Cambyses or a Darius, or any other madman, has made such attempts, and if one has killed the Egyptian Apis, I laugh at him killing their god, while pained at the outrage being perpetrated for the sake of gain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:59
verses.text: I will therefore willingly forget such villany, looking on acts like these more as deeds of covetousness, than as a proof of the impotence of idols.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:60
verses.text: But fire and earthquakes are shrewd enough not to feel shy or frightened at either demons or idols, any more than at pebbles heaped by the waves on the shore.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:61
verses.text: I know fire to be capable of exposing and curing superstition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:62
verses.text: If thou art willing to abandon this folly, the element of fire shall light thy way.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:63
verses.text: This same fire burned the temple in Argos, with Chrysis the priestess; and that of Artemis in Ephesus the second time after the Amazons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:64
verses.text: And the Capitol in Rome was often wrapped in flames; nor did the fire spare the temple of Serapis, in the city of the Alexandrians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:65
verses.text: At Athens it demolished the temple of the Eleutherian Dionysus; and as to the temple of Apollo at Delphi, first a storm assailed it, and then the discerning fire utterly destroyed it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:66
verses.text: This is told as the preface of what the fire promises.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:67
verses.text: And the makers of images, do they not shame those of you who are wise into despising matter? The Athenian Phidias inscribed on the finger of the Olympian Jove, Pantarkes is beautiful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:68
verses.text: It was not Zeus that was beautiful in his eyes, but the man he loved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:69
verses.text: And Praxiteles, as Posidippus relates in his book about Cnidus, when he fashioned the statue of Aphrodite of Cnidus, made it like the form of Cratine, of whom he was enamoured, that the miserable people might have the paramour of Praxiteles to worship.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:70
verses.text: And when Phryne the courtesan, the Thespian, was in her bloom, all the painters made their pictures of Aphrodite copies of the beauty of Phryne; as, again, the sculptors at Athens made their Mercuries like Alcibiades.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:71
verses.text: It remains for you to judge whether you ought to worship courtesans.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:72
verses.text: Moved, as I believe, by such facts, and despising such fables, the ancient kings unblushingly proclaimed themselves gods, as this involved no danger from men, and thus taught that on account of their glory they were made immortal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:73
verses.text: Ceux, the son of Eolus, was styled Zeus by his wife Alcyone; Alcyone, again, being by her husband styled Hera.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:74
verses.text: Ptolemy the Fourth was called Dionysus; and Mithridates of Pontus was also called Dionysus; and Alexander wished to be considered the son of Ammon, and to have his statue made horned by the sculptors—eager to disgrace the beauty of the human form by the addition of a horn.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:75
verses.text: And not kings only, but private persons dignified themselves with the names of deities, as Menecrates the physician, who took the name of Zeus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:76
verses.text: What need is there for me to instance Alexarchus? He, having been by profession a grammarian, assumed the character of the sun-god, as Aristus of Salamis relates.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:77
verses.text: And why mention Nicagorus? He was a native of Zela in Pontus, and lived in the days of Alexander.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:78
verses.text: Nicagorus was styled Hermes, and used the dress of Hermes, as he himself testifies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:79
verses.text: And whilst whole nations, and cities with all their inhabitants, sinking into self-flattery, treat the myths about the gods with contempt, at the same time men themselves, assuming the air of equality with the gods, and being puffed up with vainglory, vote themselves extravagant honours.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:80
verses.text: There is the case of the Macedonian Philip of Pella, the son of Amyntor, to whom they decreed divine worship in Cynosargus, although his collar-bone was broken, and he had a lame leg, and had one of his eyes knocked out.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:81
verses.text: And again that of Demetrius, who was raised to the rank of the gods; and where he alighted from his horse on his entrance into Athens is the temple of Demetrius the Alighter; and altars were raised to him everywhere, and nuptials with Athene assigned to him by the Athenians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:82
verses.text: But he disdained the goddess, as he could not marry the statue; and taking the courtesan Lamia, he ascended the Acropolis, and lay with her on the couch of Athene, showing to the old virgin the postures of the young courtesan.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:83
verses.text: There is no cause for indignation, then, at Hippo, who immortalized his own death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:84
verses.text: For this Hippo ordered the following elegy to be inscribed on his tomb:—  "This is the sepulchre of Hippo, whom Destiny Made, through death, equal to the immortal gods".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:85
verses.text: Well done, Hippo! thou showest to us the delusion of men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:86
verses.text: If they did not believe thee speaking, now that thou art dead, let them become thy disciples.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:87
verses.text: This is the oracle of Hippo; let us consider it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:88
verses.text: The objects of your worship were once men, and in process of time died; and fable and time have raised them to honour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:89
verses.text: For somehow, what is present is wont to be despised through familiarity; but what is past, being separated through the obscurity of time from the temporary censure that attached to it, is invested with honour by fiction, so that the present is viewed with distrust, the past with admiration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:90
verses.text: Exactly in this way is it, then, that the dead men of antiquity, being reverenced through the long prevalence of delusion respecting them, are regarded as gods by posterity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:91
verses.text: As grounds of your belief in these, there are your mysteries, your solemn assemblies, bonds and wounds, and weeping deities.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:92
verses.text: "Woe, woe! that fate decrees my best-belov'd, Sarpedon, by Patroclus' hand to fall".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:93
verses.text: The will of Zeus was overruled; and Zeus being worsted, laments for Sarpedon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:94
verses.text: With reason, therefore, have you yourselves called them shades and demons, since Homer, paying Athene and the other divinities sinister honour, has styled them demons:—  "She her heavenward course pursued To join the immortals in the abode of Jove".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:95
verses.text: How, then, can shades and demons be still reckoned gods, being in reality unclean and impure spirits, acknowledged by all to be of an earthly and watery nature, sinking downwards by their own weight, and flitting about graves and tombs, about which they appear dimly, being but  shadowy phantasms? Such things are your gods—shades and shadows; and to these add those maimed, wrinkled, squinting divinities the Litae, daughters of Thersites rather than of Zeus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:96
verses.text: So that Bion—wittily, as I think—says, How in reason could men pray Zeus for a beautiful progeny,—a thing he could not obtain for himself?  The incorruptible being, as far as in you lies, you sink in the earth; and that pure and holy essence you have buried in the grave, robbing the divine of its true nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:97
verses.text: Why, I pray you, have you assigned the prerogatives of God to what are no gods? Why, let me ask, have you forsaken heaven to pay divine honour to earth? What else is gold, or silver, or steel, or iron, or brass, or ivory, or precious stones? Are they not earth, and of the earth?  Are not all these things which you look on the progeny of one mother—the earth?  Why, then, foolish and silly men (for I will repeat it), have you, defaming the supercelestial region, dragged religion to the ground, by fashioning to yourselves gods of earth, and by going after those created objects, instead of the uncreated Deity, have sunk into deepest darkness?  The Parian stone is beautiful, but it is not yet Poseidon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:98
verses.text: The ivory is beautiful, but it is not yet the Olympian Zeus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:99
verses.text: Matter always needs art to fashion it, but the deity needs nothing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:100
verses.text: Art has come forward to do its work, and the matter is clothed with its shape; and while the preciousness of the material makes it capable of being turned to profitable account, it is only on account of its form that it comes to be deemed worthy of veneration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:101
verses.text: Thy image, if considered as to its origin, is gold, it is wood, it is stone, it is earth, which has received shape from the artist's hand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:102
verses.text: But I have been in the habit of walking on the earth, not of worshipping it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:103
verses.text: For I hold it wrong to entrust my spirit's hopes to things destitute of the breath of life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:104
verses.text: We must therefore approach as close as possible to the images.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:105
verses.text: How peculiarly inherent deceit is in them, is manifest from their very look.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:106
verses.text: For the forms of the images are plainly stamped with the characteristic nature of demons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:107
verses.text: If one go round and inspect the pictures and images, he will at a glance recognise your gods from their shameful forms: Dionysus from his robe; Hephaestus from his art; Demeter from her calamity; Ino from her head-dress; Poseidon from his trident; Zeus from the swan; the pyre indicates Heracles; and if one sees a statue of a naked woman without an inscription, he understands it to be the golden Aphrodite.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:108
verses.text: Thus that Cyprian Pygmalion became enamoured of an image of ivory: the image was Aphrodite, and it was nude.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:109
verses.text: The Cyprian is made a conquest of by the mere shape, and embraces the image.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:110
verses.text: This is related by Philostephanus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:111
verses.text: A different Aphrodite in Cnidus was of stone, and beautiful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:112
verses.text: Another person became enamoured of it, and shamefully embraced the stone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:113
verses.text: Posidippus relates this.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:114
verses.text: The former of these authors, in his book on Cyprus, and the latter in his book on Cnidus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:115
verses.text: So powerful is art to delude, by seducing amorous men into the pit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:116
verses.text: Art is powerful, but it cannot deceive reason, nor those who live agreeably to reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:117
verses.text: The doves on the picture were represented so to the life by the painter's art, that the pigeons flew to them; and horses have neighed to well-executed pictures of mares.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:118
verses.text: They say that a girl became enamoured of an image, and a comely youth of the statue at Cnidus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:119
verses.text: But it was the eyes of the spectators that were deceived by art; for no one in his senses ever would have embraced a goddess, or entombed himself with a lifeless paramour, or become enamoured of a demon and a stone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:120
verses.text: But it is with a different kind of spell that art deludes you, if it leads you not to the indulgence of amorous affections: it leads you to pay religious honour and worship to images and pictures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:121
verses.text: The picture is like.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:122
verses.text: Well and good! Let art receive its meed of praise, but let it not deceive man by passing itself off for truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:123
verses.text: The horse stands quiet; the dove flutters not, its wing is motionless.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:124
verses.text: But the cow of Daedalus, made of wood, allured the savage bull; and art having deceived him, compelled him to meet a woman full of licentious passion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:125
verses.text: Such frenzy have mischief-working arts created in the minds of the insensate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:126
verses.text: On the other hand, apes are admired by those who feed and care for them, because nothing in the shape of images and girls' ornaments of wax or clay deceives them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:127
verses.text: You then will show yourselves inferior to apes by cleaving to stone, and wood, and gold, and ivory images, and to pictures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:128
verses.text: Your makers of such mischievous toys—the sculptors and makers of images, the painters and workers in metal, and the poets—have introduced a motley crowd of divinities: in the fields, Satyrs and Pans; in the woods, Nymphs, and Oreads, and Hamadryads; and besides, in the waters, the rivers, and fountains, the Naiads; and in the sea the Nereids.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:129
verses.text: And now the Magi boast that the demons are the ministers of their impiety, reckoning them among the number of their domestics, and by their charms compelling them to be their slaves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:130
verses.text: Besides, the nuptials of the deities, their begetting and bringing forth of children that are recounted, their adulteries celebrated in song, their carousals represented in comedy, and bursts of laughter over their cups, which your authors introduce, urge me to cry out, though I would fain be silent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:131
verses.text: Oh the godlessness! You have turned heaven into a stage;  the Divine has become a drama; and what is sacred you have acted in comedies under the masks of demons, travestying true religion by your demon-worship superstition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:132
verses.text: "But he, striking the lyre, began to sing beautifully".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:133
verses.text: Sing to us, Homer, that beautiful song  "About the amours of Ares and Venus with the beautiful crown: How first they slept together in the palace of Hephaestus Secretly; and he gave many gifts, and dishonoured the bed and chamber of king Hephaestus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:134
verses.text: Stop, O Homer, the song! It is not beautiful; it teaches adultery, and we are prohibited from polluting our ears with hearing about adultery for we are they who bear about with us, in this living and moving image of our human nature, the likeness of God,—a likeness which dwells with us, takes counsel with us, associates with us, is a guest with us, feels with us, feels for us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:135
verses.text: We have become a consecrated offering to God for Christ's sake: we are the chosen generation, the royal priesthood, the holy nation, the peculiar people, who once were not a people, but are now the people of God; who, according to John, are not of those who are beneath, but have learned all from Him who came from above; who have come to understand the dispensation of God; who have learned to walk in newness of life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:136
verses.text: But these are not the sentiments of the many; but, casting off shame and fear, they depict in their houses the unnatural passions of the demons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:137
verses.text: Accordingly, wedded to impurity, they adorn their bed-chambers with painted tablets hung up in them, regarding licentiousness as religion; and lying in bed, in the midst of their embraces, they look on that Aphrodite locked in the embrace of her paramour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:138
verses.text: And in the hoops of their rings they cut a representation of the amorous bird that fluttered round Leda,—having a strong predilection for representations of effeminacy,—and use a seal stamped with an impression of the licentiousness of Zeus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:139
verses.text: Such are examples of your voluptuousness, such are the theologies of vice, such are the instructions of your gods, who commit fornication along with you; for what one wishes, that he thinks, according to the Athenian orator.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:140
verses.text: And of what kind, on the other hand, are your other images? Diminutive Pans, and naked girls, and drunken Satyrs, and phallic tokens, painted naked in pictures disgraceful for filthiness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:141
verses.text: And more than this: you are not ashamed in the eyes of all to look at representations of all forms of licentiousness which are portrayed in public places, but set them up and guard them with scrupulous care, consecrating these pillars of shamelessness at home, as if, forsooth, they were the images of your gods, depicting on them equally the postures of Philaenis and the labours of Heracles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:142
verses.text: Not only the use of these, but the sight of them, and the very hearing of them, we denounce as deserving the doom of oblivion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:143
verses.text: Your ears are debauched, your eyes commit fornication, your looks commit adultery before you embrace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:144
verses.text: O ye that have done violence to man, and have devoted to shame what is divine in this handiwork of God, you disbelieve everything that you may indulge your passions, and that ye may believe in idols, because you have a craving after their licentiousness, but disbelieve God, because you cannot bear a life of self-restraint.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:145
verses.text: You have hated what was better, and valued what was worse, having been spectators indeed of virtue, but actors of vice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:146
verses.text: Happy, therefore, so to say, alone are all those with one accord,—  "Who shall refuse to look on any temples And altars, worthless seats of dumb stones, And idols of stone, and images made by hands, Stained with the life's-blood, and with sacrifices Of quadrupeds, and bipeds, and fowls, and butcheries of wild beasts".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:147
verses.text: For we are expressly prohibited from exercising a deceptive art: "For thou shalt not make," says the prophet, "the likeness of anything which is in heaven above or in the earth beneath".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:148
verses.text: For can we possibly any longer suppose the Demeter, and the Core, and the mystic Iacchus of Praxiteles, to be gods, and not rather regard the art of Leucippus, or the hands of Apelles, which clothed the material with the form of the divine glory, as having a better title to the honour? But while you bestow the greatest pains that the image may be fashioned with the most exquisite beauty possible, you exercise no care to guard against your becoming like images for stupidity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:149
verses.text: Accordingly, with the utmost clearness and brevity, the prophetic word condemns this practice: "For all the gods of the nations are the images of demons; but God made the heavens, and what is in heaven".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:150
verses.text: Some, however, who have fallen into error, I know not how, worship God's work instead of God Himself,—the sun and the moon, and the rest of the starry choir,—absurdly imagining these, which are but instruments for measuring time, to be gods; "for by His word they were established, and all their host by the breath of His mouth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:151
verses.text: Human art, moreover, produces houses, and ships, and cities, and pictures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:152
verses.text: But how shall I tell what God makes? Behold the whole universe; it is His work: and the heaven, and  the sun, and angels, and men, are the works of His fingers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:153
verses.text: How great is the power of God! His bare volition was the creation of the universe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:154
verses.text: For God alone made it, because He alone is truly God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:155
verses.text: By the bare exercise of volition He creates; His mere willing was followed by the springing into being of what He willed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:156
verses.text: Consequently the choir of philosophers are in error, who indeed most nobly confess that man was made for the contemplation of the heavens, but who worship the objects that appear in the heavens and are apprehended by sight.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:157
verses.text: For if the heavenly bodies are not the works of men, they were certainly created for man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:158
verses.text: Let none of you worship the sun, but set his desires on the Maker of the sun; nor deify the universe, but seek after the Creator of the universe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:159
verses.text: The only refuge, then, which remains for him who would reach the portals of salvation is divine wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 4:160
verses.text: From this, as from a sacred asylum, the man who presses after salvation, can be dragged by no demon.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 5—The Opinions of the Philosophers Respecting God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:2
verses.text: Let us then run over, if you choose, the opinions of the philosophers, to which they give boastful utterance, respecting the gods; that we may discover philosophy itself, through its conceit making an idol of matter; although we are able to show, as we proceed, that even while deifying certain demons, it has a dream of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:3
verses.text: The elements were designated as the first principles of all things by some of them: by Thales of Miletus, who celebrated water, and Anaximenes, also of Miletus, who celebrated air as the first principle of all things, and was followed afterwards by Diogenes of Apollonia.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:4
verses.text: Parmenides of Elia introduced fire and earth as gods; one of which, namely fire, Hippasus of Metapontum and Heraclitus of Ephesus supposed a divinity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:5
verses.text: Empedocles of Agrigentum fell in with a multitude, and, in addition to those four elements, enumerates disagreement and agreement.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:6
verses.text: Atheists surely these are to be reckoned, who through an unwise wisdom worshipped matter, who did not indeed pay religious honour to stocks and stones, but deified earth, the mother of these,—who did not make an image of Poseidon, but revered water itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:7
verses.text: For what else, according to the original signification, is Poseidon, but a moist substance? the name being derived from posis (drink); as, beyond doubt, the warlike Ares is so called, from arsis (rising up) and anoeresis (destroying).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:8
verses.text: For this reason mainly, I think, many fix a sword into the ground, and sacrifice to it as to Ares.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:9
verses.text: The Scythians have a practice of this nature, as Eudoxus tells us in the second book of his Travels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:10
verses.text: The Sauromatae, too, a tribe of the Scythians, worship a sabre, as Ikesius says in his work on Mysteries.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:11
verses.text: This was also the case with Heraclitus and his followers, who worshipped fire as the first cause; for this fire others named Hephaestus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:12
verses.text: The Persian Magi, too, and many of the inhabitants of Asia, worshipped fire; and besides them, the Macedonians, as Diogenes relates in the first book of his Persica.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:13
verses.text: Why specify the Sauromatae, who are said by Nymphodorus, in his Barbaric Customs, to pay sacred honours to fire? or the Persians, or the Medes, or the Magi? These, Dino tells us, sacrifice beneath the open sky, regarding fire and water as the only images of the gods.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:14
verses.text: Nor have I failed to reveal their ignorance; for, however much they think to keep clear of error in one form, they slide into it in another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:15
verses.text: They have not supposed stocks and stones to be images of the gods, like the Greeks; nor ibises and ichneumons, like the Egyptians; but fire and water, as philosophers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:16
verses.text: Berosus, in the third book of his Chaldaics, shows that it was after many successive periods of years that men worshipped images of human shape, this practice being introduced by Artaxerxes, the son of Darius, and father of Ochus, who first set up the image of Aphrodite Anaitis at Babylon and Susa; and Ecbatana set the example of worshipping it to the Persians; the Bactrians, to Damascus and Sardis.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:17
verses.text: Let the philosophers, then, own as their teachers the Persians, or the Sauromatae, or the Magi, from whom they have learned the impious doctrine of regarding as divine certain first principles, being ignorant of the great First Cause, the Maker of all things, and Creator of those very first principles, the unbeginning God, but reverencing "these weak and beggarly elements," as the apostle says, which were made for the service of man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:18
verses.text: And of the rest of the philosophers who, passing over the elements, have eagerly sought after something higher and nobler, some have discanted on the Infinite, of whom were Anaximander of Miletus, Anaxagoras of Clazomenae, and the Athenian Archelaus, both of whom set Mind (νοῦς) above Infinity; while the Milesian Leucippus and the Chian Metrodorus apparently inculcated two first principles—fulness and vacuity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:19
verses.text: Democritus of Abdera, while accepting these two, added to them images ει ῎δωλα; while Alcmaeon of Crotona supposed the stars to be gods, and endowed with life (I will not keep silence as to their effrontery).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:20
verses.text: Xenocrates of Chalcedon indicates that the planets are seven gods, and that the universe,  composed of all these, is an eighth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:21
verses.text: Nor will I pass over those of the Porch, who say that the Divinity pervades all matter, even the vilest, and thus clumsily disgrace philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:22
verses.text: Nor do I think will it be taken ill, having reached this point, to advert to the Peripatetics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:23
verses.text: The father of this sect, not knowing the Father of all things, thinks that He who is called the Highest is the soul of the universe; that is, he supposes the soul of the world to be God, and so is pierced by his own sword.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:24
verses.text: For by first limiting the sphere of Providence to the orbit of the moon, and then by supposing the universe to be God, he confutes himself, inasmuch as he teaches that that which is without God is God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:25
verses.text: And that Eresian Theophrastus, the pupil of Aristotle, conjectures at one time heaven, and at another spirit, to be God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:26
verses.text: Epicurus alone I shall gladly forget, who carries impiety to its full length, and thinks that God takes no charge of the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 5:27
verses.text: What, moreover, of Heraclides of Pontus? He is dragged everywhere to the images—the εἴδωλα— of Democritus.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 6—By Divine Inspiration Philosophers Sometimes Hit on the Truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:2
verses.text: A great crowd of this description rushes on my mind, introducing, as it were, a terrifying apparition of strange demons, speaking of fabulous and monstrous shapes, in old wives' talk.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:3
verses.text: Far from enjoining men to listen to such tales are we, who avoid the practice of soothing our crying children, as the saying is, by telling them fabulous stories, being afraid of fostering in their minds the impiety professed by those who, though wise in their own conceit, have no more knowledge of the truth than infants.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:4
verses.text: For why (in the name of truth!) do you make those who believe you subject to ruin and corruption, dire and irretrievable? Why, I beseech you, fill up life with idolatrous images, by feigning the winds, or the air, or fire, or earth, or stones, or stocks, or steel, or this universe, to be gods; and, prating loftily of the heavenly bodies in this much vaunted science of astrology, not astronomy, to those men who have truly wandered, talk of the wandering stars as gods? It is the Lord of the spirits, the Lord of the fire, the Maker of the universe, Him who lighted up the sun, that I long for.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:5
verses.text: I seek after God, not the works of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:6
verses.text: Whom shall I take as a helper in my inquiry? We do not, if you have no objection, wholly disown Plato.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:7
verses.text: How, then, is God to be searched out, O Plato? "For both to find the Father and Maker of this universe is a work of difficulty; and having found Him, to declare Him fully, is impossible".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:8
verses.text: Why so? by Himself, I beseech you! For He can by no means be expressed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:9
verses.text: Well done, Plato! Thou hast touched on the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:10
verses.text: But do not flag.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:11
verses.text: Undertake with me the inquiry respecting the Good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:12
verses.text: For into all men whatever, especially those who are occupied with intellectual pursuits, a certain divine effluence has been instilled; wherefore, though reluctantly, they confess that God is one, indestructible, unbegotten, and that somewhere above in the tracts of heaven, in His own peculiar appropriate eminence, whence He surveys all things, He has an existence true and eternal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:13
verses.text: "Tell me what I am to conceive God to be, Who sees all things, and is Himself unseen,"  Euripides says.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:14
verses.text: Accordingly, Menander seems to me to have fallen into error when he said:—  "O sun! for thou, first of gods, ought to be worshipped, By whom it is that we are able to see the other gods".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:15
verses.text: For the sun never could show me the true God; but that healthful Word, that is the Sun of the soul, by whom alone, when He arises in the depths of the soul, the eye of the soul itself is irradiated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:16
verses.text: Whence accordingly, Democritus, not without reason, says, "that a few of the men of intellect, raising their hands upwards to what we Greeks now call the air (ἀήρ), called the whole expanse Zeus, or God: He, too, knows all things, gives and takes away, and He is King of all".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:17
verses.text: Of the same sentiments is Plato, who somewhere alludes to God thus: "Around the King of all are all things, and He is the cause of all good things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:18
verses.text: Who, then, is the King of all? God, who is the measure of the truth of all existence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:19
verses.text: As, then, the things that are to be measured are contained in the measure, so also the knowledge of God measures and comprehends truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:20
verses.text: And the truly holy Moses says: "There shall not be in thy bag a balance and a balance, great or small, but a true and just balance shall be to thee," deeming the balance and measure and number of the whole to be God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:21
verses.text: For the unjust and unrighteous idols are hid at home in the bag, and, so to speak, in the polluted soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:22
verses.text: But the only just measure is the only true God, always just, continuing the self-same; who measures all things, and weighs them by righteousness as in a balance, grasping and sustaining universal nature in equilibrium.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:23
verses.text: "God, therefore, as the old saying has it, occupying the beginning, the middle, and the end of all that is in being, keeps the straight course, while He makes the circuit of nature; and justice always follows Him, avenging those who violate the divine law".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:24
verses.text: Whence, O Plato, is that hint of the truth which thou givest? Whence this rich copiousness  of diction, which proclaims piety with oracular utterance? The tribes of the barbarians, he says, are wiser than these; I know thy teachers, even if thou wouldst conceal them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:25
verses.text: You have learned geometry from the Egyptians, astronomy from the Babylonians; the charms of healing you have got from the Thracians; the Assyrians also have taught you many things; but for the laws that are consistent with truth, and your sentiments respecting God, you are indebted to the Hebrews,  "Who do not worship through vain deceits The works of men, of gold, and brass, and silver, and ivory, And images of dead men, of wood and stone, Which other men, led by their foolish inclinations, worship; But raise to heaven pure arms: When they rise from bed, purifying themselves with water, And worship alone the Eternal, who reigns for ever more".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:26
verses.text: And let it not be this one man alone—Plato; but, O philosophy, hasten to produce many others also, who declare the only true God to be God, through His inspiration, if in any measure they have grasped the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:27
verses.text: For Antisthenes did not think out this doctrine of the Cynics; but it is in virtue of his being a disciple of Socrates that he says, "that God is not like to any; wherefore no one can know Him from an image".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:28
verses.text: And Xenophon the Athenian would have in his own person committed freely to writing somewhat of the truth, and given the same testimony as Socrates, had he not been afraid of the cup of poison, which Socrates had to drink.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:29
verses.text: But he hints nothing less; he says: "How great and powerful He is who moves all things, and is Himself at rest, is manifest; but what He is in form is not revealed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:30
verses.text: The sun himself, intended to be the source of light to all around, does not deem it fitting to allow himself to be looked at; but if any one audaciously gazes on him, he is deprived of sight".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:31
verses.text: Whence, then, does the son of Gryllus learn his wisdom? Is it not manifestly from the prophetess of the Hebrews who prophesies in the following style?—  "What flesh can see with the eye the celestial, The true, the immortal God, who inhabits the vault of heaven? Nay, men born mortal cannot even stand Before the rays of the sun".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:32
verses.text: Cleanthes Pisadeus, the Stoic philosopher, who exhibits not a poetic theogony, but a true theology, has not concealed what sentiments he entertained respecting God:—  "If you ask me what is the nature of the good, listen: That which is regular, just, holy, pious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:33
verses.text: Self-governing, useful, fair, fitting, Grave, independent, always beneficial; That feels no fear or grief; profitable, painless, Helpful, pleasant, safe, friendly; Held in esteem, agreeing with itself, honourable; Humble, careful, meek, zealous, Perennial, blameless, ever-during: Mean is every one who looks to opinion With the view of obtaining some advantage from it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:34
verses.text: Here, as I think, he clearly teaches of what nature God is; and that the common opinion and religious customs enslave those that follow them, but seek not after God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:35
verses.text: We must not either keep the Pythagoreans in the background, who say: "God is one; and He is not, as some suppose, outside of this frame of things, but within it; but, in all the entireness of His being, is in the whole circle of existence, surveying all nature, and blending in harmonious union the whole,—the author of all His own forces and works, the giver of light in heaven, and Father of all,—the mind and vital power of the whole world,—the mover of all things".
