verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 6:36
verses.text: For the knowledge of God, these utterances, written by those we have mentioned through the inspiration of God, and selected by us, may suffice even for the man that has but small power to examine into truth.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 7—The Poets Also Bear Testimony to the Truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:2
verses.text: Let poetry also approach to us (for philosophy alone will not suffice): poetry which is wholly occupied with falsehood—which scarcely will make confession of the truth, but will rather own to God its deviations into fable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:3
verses.text: Let whoever of those poets chooses advance first.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:4
verses.text: Aratus considers that the power of God pervades all things:—  "That all may be secure, Him ever they propitiate first and last, Hail, Father I great marvel, great gain to man".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:5
verses.text: Thus also the Ascraean Hesiod dimly speaks of God:—  "For He is the King of all, and monarch Of the immortals; and there is none that may vie with Him in power".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:6
verses.text: Also on the stage they reveal the truth:—  "Look on the ether and heaven, and regard that as God,"  says Euripides.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:7
verses.text: And Sophocles, the son of Sophilus, says:—  "One, in truth, one is God, Who made both heaven and the far-stretching earth, And ocean's blue wave, and the mighty winds; But many of us mortals, deceived in heart, Have set up for ourselves, as a consolation in our afflictions, Images of the gods of stone, or wood, or brass, Or gold, or ivory; And, appointing to those sacrifices and vain festal assemblages, Are accustomed thus to practice religion".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:8
verses.text: In this venturous manner has he on the stage brought truth before the spectators.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:9
verses.text: But the Thracian Orpheus, the son of oeagrus, hierophant and poet at once, after his exposition of the orgies, and his theology of idols, introduces a palinode of truth with true solemnity, though tardily singing the strain:—  "I shall utter to whom it is lawful; but let the doors be closed, Nevertheless, against all the profane.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:10
verses.text: But do thou hear, O Musaeus, offspring of the light-bringing moon, For I will declare what is true.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:11
verses.text: And let not these things Which once appeared in your breast rob you of dear life; But looking to the divine word, apply yourself to it, Keeping right the seat of intellect and feeling; and walk well In the straight path, and to the immortal King of the universe alone Direct your gaze".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:12
verses.text: Then proceeding, he clearly adds:—  "He is one, self-proceeding; and from Him alone all things proceed, And in them He Himself exerts his activity: no mortal Beholds Him, but He beholds all".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:13
verses.text: Thus far Orpheus at last understood that he had been in error:—  "But linger no longer, O man, endued with varied wisdom; But turn and retrace your steps, and propitiate God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:14
verses.text: For if, at the most, the Greeks, having received certain scintillations of the divine word, have given forth some utterances of truth, they bear indeed witness that the force of truth is not hidden, and at the same time expose their own weakness in not having arrived at the end.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:15
verses.text: For I think it has now become evident to all, that those who do or speak aught without the word of truth are like people compelled to walk without feet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:16
verses.text: Let the strictures on your gods, which the poets, impelled by the force of truth, introduce in their comedies, shame you into salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:17
verses.text: Menander, for instance, the comic poet, in his drama of the Charioteer, says:—  "No God pleases me that goes about With an old woman, and enters houses Carrying a trencher".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:18
verses.text: For such are the begging priests of Cybele.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:19
verses.text: Hence Antisthenes replies appropriately to their request for alms:—  "I do not maintain the mother of the gods, For the gods maintain her".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:20
verses.text: Again, the same writer of comedy, expressing his dissatisfaction with the common usages, tries to expose the impious arrogance of the prevailing error in the drama of the Priestess, sagely declaring:—  "If a man drags the Deity Whither he will by the sound of cymbals, He that does this is greater than the Deity; But these are the instruments of audacity and means of living Invented by men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:21
verses.text: And not only Menander, but Homer also, and Euripides, and other poets in great numbers, expose your gods, and are wont to rate them, and that soundly too.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:22
verses.text: For instance, they call Aphrodite dog-fly, and Hephaestus a cripple.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:23
verses.text: Helen says to Aphrodite:—  "Thy godship abdicate! Renounce Olympus!"  And of Dionysus, Homer writes without reserve:—  "He, mid their frantic orgies, in the groves Of lovely Nyssa, put to shameful rout The youthful Bacchus' nurses; they in fear, Dropped each her thyrsus, scattered by the hand Of fierce Lycurgus, with an ox-goad armed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:24
verses.text: Worthy truly of the Socratic school is Euripides, who fixes his eye on truth, and despises the spectators of his plays.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:25
verses.text: On one occasion, Apollo,  "Who inhabits the sanctuary that is in the middle of the earth, Dispensing most certain oracles to mortals,"  is thus exposed:—  "It was in obedience to him that I killed her who brought me forth; Him do you regard as stained with guilt—put him to death; It was he that sinned, not I, uninstructed as I was In right and justice".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:26
verses.text: He introduces Heracles, at one time mad, at another drunk and gluttonous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 7:27
verses.text: How should he not so represent the god who, when entertained as a guest, ate green figs to flesh, uttering discordant howls, that even his barbarian host remarked it? In his drama of Ion, too, he barefacedly brings the gods on the stage:—  "How, then, is it right for you, who have given laws to mortals, To be yourselves guilty of wrong? And if—what will never take place, yet I will state the supposition— You will give satisfaction to men for your adulteries, You, Poseidon, and you, Zeus, the ruler of heaven,— You will, in order to make recompense for your misdeeds, Have to empty your temples".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 8—The True Doctrine is to Be Sought in the Prophets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:2
verses.text: It is now time, as we have despatched in order the other points, to go to the prophetic Scriptures; for the oracles present us with the appliances necessary for the attainment of piety,  and so establish the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:3
verses.text: The divine Scriptures and institutions of wisdom form the short road to salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:4
verses.text: Devoid of embellishment, of outward beauty of diction, of wordiness and seductiveness, they raise up humanity strangled by wickedness, teaching men to despise the casualties of life; and with one and the same voice remedying many evils, they at once dissuade us from pernicious deceit, and clearly exhort us to the attainment of the salvation set before us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:5
verses.text: Let the Sibyl prophetess, then, be the first to sing to us the song of salvation:—  "So He is all sure and unerring: Come, follow no longer darkness and gloom; See, the sun's sweet-glancing light shines gloriously.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:6
verses.text: Know, and lay up wisdom in your hearts: There is one God, who sends rains, and winds, and earthquakes, Thunderbolts, famines, plagues, and dismal sorrows, And snows and ice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:7
verses.text: But why detail particulars? He reigns over heaven, He rules earth, He truly is;"—  where, in remarkable accordance with inspiration she compares delusion to darkness, and the knowledge of God to the sun and light, and subjecting both to comparison, shows the choice we ought to make.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:8
verses.text: For falsehood is not dissipated by the bare presentation of the truth, but by the practical improvement of the truth it is ejected and put to flight.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:9
verses.text: Jeremiah the prophet, gifted with consummate wisdom, or rather the Holy Spirit in Jeremiah, exhibits God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:10
verses.text: "Am I a God at hand," he says, "and not a God afar off? Shall a man do ought in secret, and I not see him? Do I not fill heaven and earth? Saith the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:11
verses.text: And again by Isaiah, "Who shall measure heaven with a span, and the whole earth with his hand?" Behold God's greatness, and be filled with amazement.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:12
verses.text: Let us worship Him of whom the prophet says, "Before Thy face the hills shall melt, as wax melteth before the fire!" This, says he, is the God "whose throne is heaven, and His footstool the earth; and if He open heaven, quaking will seize thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:13
verses.text: Will you hear, too, what this prophet says of idols? "And they shall be made a spectacle of in the face of the sun, and their carcases shall be meat for the fowls of heaven and the wild beasts of the earth; and they shall putrefy before the sun and the moon, which they have loved and served; and their city shall be burned down".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:14
verses.text: He says, too, that the elements and the world shall be destroyed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:15
verses.text: "The earth," he says, "shall grow old, and the heaven shall pass away; but the word of the Lord endureth for ever".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:16
verses.text: What, then, when again God wishes to show Himself by Moses: "Behold ye, behold ye, that I Am, and there is no other God beside Me.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:17
verses.text: I will kill, and I will make to live; I will strike, and I will heal; and there is none who shall deliver out of My hands".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:18
verses.text: But do you wish to hear another seer? You have the whole prophetic choir, the associates of Moses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:19
verses.text: What the Holy Spirit says by Hosea, I will not shrink from quoting: "Lo, I am He that appointeth the thunder, and createth spirit; and His hands have established the host of heaven".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:20
verses.text: And once more by Isaiah.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:21
verses.text: And this utterance I will repeat: "I am," he says, "I am the Lord; I who speak righteousness, announce truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:22
verses.text: Gather yourselves together, and come.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:23
verses.text: Take counsel together, ye that are saved from the nations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:24
verses.text: They have not known, they who set up the block of wood, their carved work, and pray to gods who will not save them".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:25
verses.text: Then proceeding: "I am God, and there is not beside Me a just God, and a Saviour: there is none except Me.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:26
verses.text: Turn to Me, and ye will be saved, ye that are from the end of the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:27
verses.text: I am God, and there is no other; by Myself I swear".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:28
verses.text: But against the worshippers of idols he is exasperated, saying, "To whom will ye liken the Lord, or to what likeness will ye compare Him? Has not the artificer made the image, or the goldsmith melted the gold and plated it with gold?"—and so on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:29
verses.text: Be not therefore idolaters, but even now beware of the threatenings; "for the graven images and the works of men's hands shall wail, or rather they that trust in them," for matter is devoid of sensation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:30
verses.text: Once more he says, "The Lord will shake the cities that are inhabited, and grasp the world in His hand like a nest".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:31
verses.text: Why repeat to you the mysteries of wisdom, and sayings from the writings of the son of the Hebrews, the master of wisdom? "The Lord created me the beginning of His ways, in order to His works".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:32
verses.text: And, "The Lord giveth wisdom, and from His face proceed knowledge and understanding".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:33
verses.text: "How long wilt thou lie in bed, O sluggard; and when wilt thou be aroused from sleep?" "but if thou show thyself no  sluggard, as a fountain thy harvest shall come," the "Word of the Father, the benign light, the Lord that bringeth light, faith to all, and salvation".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:34
verses.text: For "the Lord who created the earth by His power," as Jeremiah says, "has raised up the world by His wisdom;" for wisdom, which is His word, raises us up to the truth, who have fallen prostrate before idols, and is itself the first resurrection from our fall.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:35
verses.text: Whence Moses, the man of God, dissuading from all idolatry, beautifully exclaims, "Hear, O Israel, the Lord thy God is one Lord; and thou shall worship the Lord thy God, and Him only shall thou serve".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:36
verses.text: "Now therefore be wise, O men," according to that blessed psalmist David; "lay hold on instruction, lest the Lord be angry, and ye perish from the way of righteousness, when His wrath has quickly kindled.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:37
verses.text: Blessed are all they who put their trust in Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:38
verses.text: But already the Lord, in His surpassing pity, has inspired the song of salvation, sounding like a battle march, "Sons of men, how long will ye be slow of heart? Why do you love vanity, and seek after a lie?" What, then, is the vanity, and what the lie? The holy apostle of the Lord, reprehending the Greeks, will show thee: "Because that, when they knew God, they glorified Him not as God, neither were thankful; but became vain in their imaginations, and changed the glory of God into the likeness of corruptible man, and worshipped and served the creature more than the Creator".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:39
verses.text: And verily this is the God who "in the beginning made the heaven and the earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 8:40
verses.text: But you do not know God, and worship the heaven, and how shall you escape the guilt of impiety? Hear again the prophet speaking: "The sun, shall suffer eclipse, and the heaven be darkened; but the Almighty shall shine for ever: while the powers of the heavens shall be shaken, and the heavens stretched out and drawn together shall be rolled as a parchment-skin (for these are the prophetic expressions), and the earth shall flee away from before the face of the Lord".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 9—"That Those Grievously Sin Who Despise or Neglect God's Gracious Calling".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:2
verses.text: I could adduce ten thousand Scriptures of which not "one tittle shall pass away," without being fulfilled; for the mouth of the Lord the Holy Spirit hath spoken these things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:3
verses.text: "Do not any longer," he says, "my son, despise the chastening of the Lord, nor faint when thou art rebuked of Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:4
verses.text: O surpassing love for man! Not as a teacher speaking to his pupils, not as a master to his domestics, nor as God to men, but as a father, does the Lord gently admonish his children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:5
verses.text: Thus Moses confesses that "he was filled with quaking and terror" while he listened to God speaking concerning the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:6
verses.text: And art not thou afraid as thou hearest the voice of the Divine Word? Art not thou distressed? Do you not fear, and hasten to learn of Him,—that is, to salvation,—dreading wrath, loving grace, eagerly striving after the hope set before us, that you may shun the judgment threatened? Come, come, O my young people! For if you become not again as little children, and be born again, as saith the Scripture, you shall not receive the truly existent Father, nor shall you ever enter into the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:7
verses.text: For in what way is a stranger permitted to enter? Well, as I take it, then, when he is enrolled and made a citizen, and receives one to stand to him in the relation of father, then will he be occupied with the Father's concerns, then shall he be deemed worthy to be made His heir, then will he share the kingdom of the Father with His own dear Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:8
verses.text: For this is the first-born Church, composed of many good children; these are "the first-born enrolled in heaven, who hold high festival with so many myriads of angels".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:9
verses.text: We, too, are first-born sons, who are reared by God, who are the genuine friends of the First-born, who first of all other men attained to the knowledge of God, who first were wrenched away from our sins, first severed from the devil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:10
verses.text: And now the more benevolent God is, the more impious men are; for He desires us from slaves to become sons, while they scorn to become sons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:11
verses.text: O the prodigious folly of being ashamed of the Lord! He offers freedom, you flee into bondage; He bestows salvation, you sink down into destruction; He confers everlasting life, you wait for punishment, and prefer the fire which the Lord "has prepared for the devil and his angels".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:12
verses.text: Wherefore the blessed apostle says: "I testify in the Lord, that ye walk no longer as the Gentiles walk, in the vanity of their mind; having their understanding darkened, being alienated from the life of God through the ignorance that is in them, because of the hardness of their heart: who, being past feeling, have given themselves over to lasciviousness, to work all uncleanness and concupiscence".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:13
verses.text: After the accusation of such a witness, and his invocation of God, what else remains for the unbelieving than judgment and condemnation? And the Lord, with ceaseless assiduity, exhorts, terrifies, urges, rouses,  admonishes; He awakes from the sleep of darkness, and raises up those who have wandered in error.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:14
verses.text: "Awake," He says, "thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead, and Christ shall give thee light,"—Christ, the Sun of the Resurrection, He "who was born before the morning star," and with His beams bestows life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:15
verses.text: Let no one then despise the Word, lest he unwittingly despise himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:16
verses.text: For the Scripture somewhere says, "To-day, if ye will hear His voice, harden not your hearts, as in the provocation, in the day of temptation in the wilderness, when your fathers proved Me by trial".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:17
verses.text: And what was the trial? If you wish to learn, the Holy Spirit will show you: "And saw my works," He says, "forty years.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:18
verses.text: Wherefore I was grieved with that generation, and said, They do always err in heart, and have not known My ways.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:19
verses.text: So I sware in my wrath, they shall not enter into My rest".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:20
verses.text: Look to the threatening! Look to the exhortation! Look to the punishment! Why, then, should we any longer change grace into wrath, and not receive the word with open ears, and entertain God as a guest in pure spirits? For great is the grace of His promise, "if to-day we hear His voice".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:21
verses.text: And that to-day is lengthened out day by day, while it is called to-day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:22
verses.text: And to the end the to-day and the instruction continue; and then the true to-day, the never-ending day of God, extends over eternity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:23
verses.text: Let us then ever obey the voice of the divine word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:24
verses.text: For the to-day signifies eternity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:25
verses.text: And day is the symbol of light; and the light of men is the Word, by whom we behold God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:26
verses.text: Rightly, then, to those that have believed and obey, grace will superabound; while with those that have been unbelieving, and err in heart, and have not known the Lord's ways, which John commanded to make straight and to prepare, God is incensed, and those He threatens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:27
verses.text: And, indeed, the old Hebrew wanderers in the desert received typically the end of the threatening; for they are said not to have entered into the rest, because of unbelief, till, having followed the successor of Moses, they learned by experience, though late, that they could not be saved otherwise than by believing on Jesus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:28
verses.text: But the Lord, in His love to man, invites all men to the knowledge of the truth, and for this end sends the Paraclete.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:29
verses.text: What, then, is this knowledge? Godliness; and "godliness," according to Paul, "is profitable for all things, having the promise of the life that now is, and of that which is to come".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:30
verses.text: If eternal salvation were to be sold, for how much, O men, would you propose to purchase it? Were one to estimate the value of the whole of Pactolus, the fabulous river of gold, he would not have reckoned up a price equivalent to salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:31
verses.text: Do not, however, faint.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:32
verses.text: You may, if you choose, purchase salvation, though of inestimable value, with your own resources, love and living faith, which will be reckoned a suitable price.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:33
verses.text: This recompense God cheerfully accepts; "for we trust in the living God, who is the Saviour of all men, especially of those who believe".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:34
verses.text: But the rest, round whom the world's growths have fastened, as the rocks on the sea-shore are covered over with sea-weed, make light of immortality, like the old man of Ithaca, eagerly longing to see, not the truth, not the fatherland in heaven, not the true light, but smoke.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:35
verses.text: But godliness, that makes man as far as can be like God, designates God as our suitable teacher, who alone can worthily assimilate man to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:36
verses.text: This teaching the apostle knows as truly divine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:37
verses.text: "Thou, O Timothy," he says, "from a child hast known the holy letters, which are able to make thee wise unto salvation, through faith that is in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:38
verses.text: For truly holy are those letters that sanctify and deify; and the writings or volumes that consist of those holy letters and syllables, the same apostle consequently calls "inspired of God, being profitable for doctrine, for reproof, for correction, for instruction in righteousness, that the man of God may be perfect, thoroughly furnished to every good work".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:39
verses.text: No one will be so impressed by the exhortations of any of the saints, as he is by the words of the Lord Himself, the lover of man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:40
verses.text: For this, and nothing but this, is His only work—the salvation of man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:41
verses.text: Therefore He Himself, urging them on to salvation, cries, "The kingdom of heaven is at hand".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:42
verses.text: Those men that draw near through fear, He converts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:43
verses.text: Thus also the apostle of the Lord, beseeching the Macedonians, becomes the interpreter of the divine voice, when he says, "The Lord is at hand; take care that ye be not apprehended empty".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:44
verses.text: But are ye so devoid of fear, or rather of faith, as not to believe the Lord Himself, or Paul, who in Christ's stead thus entreats: "Taste and see that Christ is God?" Faith will lead you in; experience will teach you; Scripture will train you, for it says, "Come hither, O children; listen to me, and I will teach you the fear of the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:45
verses.text: Then, as to those who already believe, it briefly adds, "What man is he that desireth life, that loveth to see good days?" It is we, we shall  say—we who are the devotees of good, we who eagerly desire good things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:46
verses.text: Hear, then, ye who are far off, hear ye who are near: the word has not been hidden from any; light is common, it shines "on all men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:47
verses.text: No one is a Cimmerian in respect to the word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:48
verses.text: Let us haste to salvation, to regeneration; let us who are many haste that we may be brought together into one love, according to the union of the essential unity; and let us, by being made good, conformably follow after union, seeking after the good Monad.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:49
verses.text: The union of many in one, issuing in the production of divine harmony out of a medley of sounds and division, becomes one symphony following one choir-leader and teacher, the Word, reaching and resting in the same truth, and crying Abba, Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 9:50
verses.text: This, the true utterance of His children, God accepts with gracious welcome—the first-fruits He receives from them.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 10—Answer to the Objection of the Heathen, that It Was Not Right to Abandon the Customs of Their Fathers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:2
verses.text: But you say it is not creditable to subvert the customs handed down to us from our fathers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:3
verses.text: And why, then, do we not still use our first nourishment, milk, to which our nurses accustomed us from the time of our birth? Why do we increase or diminish our patrimony, and not keep it exactly the same as we got it? Why do we not still vomit on our parents' breasts, or still do the things for which, when infants, and nursed by our mothers, we were laughed at, but have corrected ourselves, even if we did not fall in with good instructors? Then, if excesses in the indulgence of the passions, though pernicious and dangerous, yet are accompanied with pleasure, why do we not in the conduct of life abandon that usage which is evil, and provocative of passion, and godless, even should our fathers feel hurt, and betake ourselves to the truth, and seek Him who is truly our Father, rejecting custom as a deleterious drug? For of all that I have undertaken to do, the task I now attempt is the noblest, viz.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:4
verses.text: , to demonstrate to you how inimical this insane and most wretched custom is to godliness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:5
verses.text: For a boon so great, the greatest ever given by God to the human race, would never have been hated and rejected, had not you been carried away by custom, and then shut your ears against us; and just as unmanageable horses throw off the reins, and take the bit between their teeth, you rush away from the arguments addressed to you, in your eager desire to shake yourselves clear of us, who seek to guide the chariot of your life, and, impelled by your folly, dash towards the precipices of destruction, and regard the holy word of God as an accursed thing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:6
verses.text: The reward of your choice, therefore, as described by Sophocles, follows:—  "The mind a blank, useless ears, vain thoughts".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:7
verses.text: And you know not that, of all truths, this is the truest, that the good and godly shall obtain the good reward, inasmuch as they held goodness in high esteem; while, on the other hand, the wicked shall receive meet punishment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:8
verses.text: For the author of evil, torment has been prepared; and so the prophet Zecharias threatens him: "He that hath chosen Jerusalem rebuke thee; lo, is not this a brand plucked from the fire?" What an infatuated desire, then, for voluntary death is this, rooted in men's minds! Why do they flee to this fatal brand, with which they shall be burned, when it is within their power to live nobly according to God, and not according to custom? For God bestows life freely; but evil custom, after our departure from this world, brings on the sinner unavailing remorse with punishment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:9
verses.text: By sad experience, even a child knows how superstition destroys and piety saves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:10
verses.text: Let any of you look at those who minister before the idols, their hair matted, their persons disgraced with filthy and tattered clothes; who never come near a bath, and let their nails grow to an extraordinary length, like wild beasts; many of them castrated, who show the idol's temples to be in reality graves or prisons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:11
verses.text: These appear to me to bewail the gods, not to worship them, and their sufferings to be worthy of pity rather than piety.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:12
verses.text: And seeing these things, do you still continue blind, and will you not look up to the Ruler of all, the Lord of the universe? And will you not escape from those dungeons, and flee to the mercy that comes down from heaven? For God, of His great love to man, comes to the help of man, as the mother-bird flies to one of her young that has fallen out of the nest; and if a serpent open its mouth to swallow the little bird, "the mother flutters round, uttering cries of grief over her dear progeny;" and God the Father seeks His creature, and heals his transgression, and pursues the serpent, and recovers the young one, and incites it to fly up to the nest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:13
verses.text: Thus dogs that have strayed, track out their master by the scent; and horses that have thrown their riders, come to their master's call if he but whistle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:14
verses.text: "The ox," it is said, "knoweth his owner, and the ass his master's crib; but Israel hath not known Me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:15
verses.text: What, then, of the Lord? He remembers not our ill desert; He still pities, He still urges us to repentance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:16
verses.text: And I would ask you, if it does not appear to you monstrous, that you men who are God's handiwork, who have received your souls from Him, and belong wholly to God, should be subject to another master, and, what is more, serve the tyrant instead of the rightful King—the evil one instead of the good? For, in the name of truth, what man in his senses turns his back on good, and attaches himself to evil? What, then, is he who flees from God to consort with demons? Who, that may become a son of God, prefers to be in bondage? Or who is he that pursues his way to Erebus, when it is in his power to be a citizen of heaven, and to cultivate Paradise, and walk about in heaven and partake of the tree of life and immortality, and, cleaving his way through the sky in the track of the luminous cloud, behold, like Elias, the rain of salvation? Some there are, who, like worms wallowing in marshes and mud in the streams of pleasure, feed on foolish and useless delights—swinish men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:17
verses.text: For swine, it is said, like mud better than pure water; and, according to Democritus, "doat upon dirt".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:18
verses.text: Let us not then be enslaved or become swinish; but, as true children of the light, let us raise our eyes and look on the light, lest the Lord discover us to be spurious, as the sun does the eagles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:19
verses.text: Let us therefore repent, and pass from ignorance to knowledge, from foolishness to wisdom, from licentiousness to self-restraint, from unrighteousness to righteousness, from godlessness to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:20
verses.text: It is an enterprise of noble daring to take our way to God; and the enjoyment of many other good things is within the reach of the lovers of righteousness, who pursue eternal life, specially those things to which God Himself alludes, speaking by Isaiah: "There is an inheritance for those who serve the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:21
verses.text: Noble and desirable is this inheritance: not gold, not silver, not raiment, which the moth assails, and things of earth which are assailed by the robber, whose eye is dazzled by worldly wealth; but it is that treasure of salvation to which we must hasten, by becoming lovers of the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:22
verses.text: Thence praise-worthy works descend to us, and fly with us on the wing of truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:23
verses.text: This is the inheritance with which the eternal covenant of God invests us, conveying the everlasting gift of grace; and thus our loving Father—the true Father—ceases not to exhort, admonish, train, love us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:24
verses.text: For He ceases not to save, and advises the best course: "Become righteous," says the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:25
verses.text: Ye that thirst, come to the water; and ye that have no money, come, and buy and drink without money.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:26
verses.text: He invites to the laver, to salvation, to illumination, all but crying out and saying, The land I give thee, and the sea, my child, and heaven too; and all the living creatures in them I freely bestow upon thee.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:27
verses.text: Only, O child, thirst for thy Father; God shall be revealed to thee without price; the truth is not made merchandise of.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:28
verses.text: He gives thee all creatures that fly and swim, and those on the land.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:29
verses.text: These the Father has created for thy thankful enjoyment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:30
verses.text: What the bastard, who is a son of perdition, foredoomed to be the slave of mammon, has to buy for money, He assigns to thee as thine own, even to His own son who loves the Father; for whose sake He still works, and to whom alone He promises, saying, "The land shall not be sold in perpetuity," for it is not destined to corruption.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:31
verses.text: "For the whole land is mine;" and it is thine too, if thou receive God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:32
verses.text: Wherefore the Scripture, as might have been expected, proclaims good news to those who have believed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:33
verses.text: "The saints of the Lord shall inherit the glory of God and His power".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:34
verses.text: What glory, tell me, O blessed One, which "eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, nor hath it entered into the heart of man;" and "they shall be glad in the kingdom of their Lord for ever and ever! Amen".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:35
verses.text: You have, O men, the divine promise of grace; you have heard, on the other hand, the threatening of punishment: by these the Lord saves, teaching men by fear and grace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:36
verses.text: Why do we delay? Why do we not shun the punishment? Why do we not receive the free gift? Why, in fine, do we not choose the better part, God instead of the evil one, and prefer wisdom to idolatry, and take life in exchange for death? "Behold," He says, "I have set before your face death and life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:37
verses.text: The Lord tries you, that "you may choose life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:38
verses.text: He counsels you as a father to obey God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:39
verses.text: "For if ye hear Me," He says, "and be willing, ye shall eat the good things of the land:" this is the grace attached to obedience.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:40
verses.text: "But if ye obey Me not, and are unwilling, the sword and fire shall devour you:" this is the penalty of disobedience.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:41
verses.text: For the mouth of the Lord—the law of truth, the word of the Lord—hath spoken these things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:42
verses.text: Are you willing that I should be your good counsellor? Well, do you hear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:43
verses.text: I, if possible, will explain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:44
verses.text: You ought, O men, when reflecting on the Good, to have brought forward a witness inborn and competent, viz.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:45
verses.text: , faith, which of itself, and from its own resources, chooses at once what is best, instead of occupying yourselves in painfully inquiring whether what is best ought to be followed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:46
verses.text: For, allow me to tell you, you ought to doubt whether you should get drunk, but you get drunk before reflecting on the matter; and whether  you ought to do an injury, but you do injury with the utmost readiness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:47
verses.text: The only thing you make the subject of question is, whether God should be worshipped, and whether this wise God and Christ should be followed: and this you think requires deliberation and doubt, and know not what is worthy of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:48
verses.text: Have faith in us, as you have in drunkenness, that you may be wise; have faith in us, as you have in injury, that you may live.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:49
verses.text: But if, acknowledging the conspicuous trustworthiness of the virtues, you wish to trust them, come and I will set before you in abundance, materials of persuasion respecting the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:50
verses.text: But do you—for your ancestral customs, by which your minds are preoccupied, divert you from the truth,—do you now hear what is the real state of the case as follows.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:51
verses.text: And let not any shame of this name preoccupy you, which does great harm to men, and seduces them from salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:52
verses.text: Let us then openly strip for the contest, and nobly strive in the arena of truth, the holy Word being the judge, and the Lord of the universe prescribing the contest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:53
verses.text: For 'tis no insignificant prize, the guerdon of immortality which is set before us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:54
verses.text: Pay no more regard, then, if you are rated by some of the low rabble who lead the dance of impiety, and are driven on to the same pit by their folly and insanity, makers of idols and worshippers of stones.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:55
verses.text: For these have dared to deify men,—Alexander of Macedon, for example, whom they canonized as the thirteenth god, whose pretensions Babylon confuted, which showed him dead.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:56
verses.text: I admire, therefore, the divine sophist.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:57
verses.text: Theocritus was his name.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:58
verses.text: After Alexander's death, Theocritus, holding up the vain opinions entertained by men respecting the gods, to ridicule before his fellow-citizens, said: "Men, keep up your hearts as long as you see the gods dying sooner than men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:59
verses.text: And, truly, he who worships gods that are visible, and the promiscuous rabble of creatures begotten and born, and attaches himself to them, is a far more wretched object than the very demons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:60
verses.text: For God is by no manner of means unrighteous, as the demons are, but in the very highest degree righteous; and nothing more resembles God than one of us when he becomes righteous in the highest possible degree:—  "Go into the way, the whole tribe of you handicrafts-men, Who worship Jove's fierce-eyed daughter, the working goddess, With fans duly placed, fools that ye are"—  fashioners of stones, and worshippers of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:61
verses.text: Let your Phidias, and Polycletus, and your Praxiteles and Apelles too, come, and all that are engaged in mechanical arts, who, being themselves of the earth, are workers of the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:62
verses.text: "For then," says a certain prophecy, "the affairs here turn out unfortunately, when men put their trust in images".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:63
verses.text: Let the meaner artists, too—for I will not stop calling—come.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:64
verses.text: None of these ever made a breathing image, or out of earth moulded soft flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:65
verses.text: Who liquefied the marrow? or who solidified the bones? Who stretched the nerves? who distended the veins? Who poured the blood into them? Or who spread the skin? Who ever could have made eyes capable of seeing? Who breathed spirit into the lifeless form? Who bestowed righteousness? Who promised immortality? The Maker of the universe alone; the Great Artist and Father has formed us, such a living image as man is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:66
verses.text: But your Olympian Jove, the image of an image, greatly out of harmony with truth, is the senseless work of Attic hands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:67
verses.text: For the image of God is His Word, the genuine Son of Mind, the Divine Word, the archetypal light of light; and the image of the Word is the true man, the mind which is in man, who is therefore said to have been made "in the image and likeness of God," assimilated to the Divine Word in the affections of the soul, and therefore rational; but effigies sculptured in human form, the earthly image of that part of man which is visible and earth-born, are but a perishable impress of humanity, manifestly wide of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:68
verses.text: That life, then, which is occupied with so much earnestness about matter, seems to me to be nothing else than full of insanity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:69
verses.text: And custom, which has made you taste bondage and unreasonable care, is fostered by vain opinion; and ignorance, which has proved to the human race the cause of unlawful rites and delusive shows, and also of deadly plagues and hateful images, has, by devising many shapes of demons, stamped on all that follow it the mark of long-continued death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:70
verses.text: Receive, then, the water of the word; wash, ye polluted ones; purify yourselves from custom, by sprinkling yourselves with the drops of truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:71
verses.text: The pure must ascend to heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:72
verses.text: Thou art a man, if we look to that which is most common to thee and others—seek Him who created thee; thou art a son, if we look to that which is thy peculiar prerogative—acknowledge thy Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:73
verses.text: But do you still continue in your sins, engrossed with pleasures? To whom shall the Lord say, "Yours is the kingdom of heaven?" Yours, whose choice is set on God, if you will; yours, if you will only believe, and comply with the brief terms of the announcement; which the Ninevites having obeyed, instead of the destruction they looked for, obtained a signal deliverance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:74
verses.text: How, then,  may I ascend to heaven, is it said? The Lord is the way; a strait way, but leading from heaven, strait in truth, but leading back to heaven, strait, despised on earth; broad, adored in heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:75
verses.text: Then, he that is uninstructed in the word, has ignorance as the excuse of his error; but as for him into whose ears instruction has been poured, and who deliberately maintains his incredulity in his soul, the wiser he appears to be, the more harm will his understanding do him; for he has his own sense as his accuser for not having chosen the best part.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:76
verses.text: For man has been otherwise constituted by nature, so as to have fellowship with God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:77
verses.text: As, then, we do not compel the horse to plough, or the bull to hunt, but set each animal to that for which it is by nature fitted; so, placing our finger on what is man's peculiar and distinguishing characteristic above other creatures, we invite him—born, as he is, for the contemplation of heaven, and being, as he is, a truly heavenly plant—to the knowledge of God, counselling him to furnish himself with what is his sufficient provision for eternity, namely piety.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:78
verses.text: Practise husbandry, we say, if you are a husbandman; but while you till your fields, know God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:79
verses.text: Sail the sea, you who are devoted to navigation, yet call the whilst on the heavenly Pilot.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:80
verses.text: Has knowledge taken hold of you while engaged in military service? Listen to the commander, who orders what is right.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:81
verses.text: As those, then, who have been overpowered with sleep and drunkenness, do ye awake; and using your eyes a little, consider what mean those stones which you worship, and the expenditure you frivolously lavish on matter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:82
verses.text: Your means and substance you squander on ignorance, even as you throw away your lives to death, having found no other end of your vain hope than this.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:83
verses.text: Not only unable to pity yourselves, you are incapable even of yielding to the persuasions of those who commiserate you; enslaved as you are to evil custom, and, clinging to it voluntarily till your last breath, you are hurried to destruction: "because light is come into the world, and men have loved the darkness rather than the light," while they could sweep away those hindrances to salvation, pride, and wealth, and fear, repeating this poetic utterance:—  "Whither do I bear these abundant riches? and whither Do I myself wander?"  If you wish, then, to cast aside these vain phantasies, and bid adieu to evil custom, say to vain opinion:—  "Lying dreams, farewell; you were then nothing".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:84
verses.text: For what, think you, O men, is the Hermes of Typho, and that of Andocides, and that of Amyetus? Is it not evident to all that they are stones, as is the veritable Hermes himself? As the Halo is not a god, and as the Iris is not a god, but are states of the atmosphere and of the clouds; and as, likewise, a day is not a god, nor a year, nor time, which is made up of these, so neither is sun nor moon, by which each of those mentioned above is determined.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:85
verses.text: Who, then, in his right senses, can imagine Correction, and Punishment, and Justice, and Retribution to be gods? For neither the Furies, nor the Fates, nor Destiny are gods, since neither Government, nor Glory, nor Wealth are gods, which last as Plutus painters represent as blind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:86
verses.text: But if you deify Modesty, and Love, and Venus, let these be followed by Infamy, and Passion, and Beauty, and Intercourse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:87
verses.text: Therefore Sleep and Death cannot reasonably any more be regarded as twin deities, being merely changes which take place naturally in living creatures; no more will you with propriety call Fortune, or Destiny, or the Fates goddesses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:88
verses.text: And if Strife and Battle be not gods, no more are Ares and Enyo.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:89
verses.text: Still further, if the lightnings, and thunderbolts, and rains are not gods, how can fire and water be gods? how can shooting stars and comets, which are produced by atmospheric changes? He who calls Fortune a god, let him also so call Action.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:90
verses.text: If, then, none of these, nor of the images formed by human hands, and destitute of feeling, is held to be a God, while a providence exercised about us is evidently the result of a divine power, it remains only to acknowledge this, that He alone who is truly God, only truly is and subsists.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:91
verses.text: But those who are insensible to this are like men who have drunk mandrake or some other drug.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:92
verses.text: May God grant that you may at length awake from this slumber, and know God; and that neither Gold, nor Stone, nor Tree, nor Action, nor Suffering, nor Disease, nor Fear, may appear in your eyes as a god.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:93
verses.text: For there are, in sooth, "on the fruitful earth thrice ten thousand" demons, not immortal, nor indeed mortal; for they are not endowed with sensation, so as to render them capable of death, but only things of wood and stone, that hold despotic sway over men insulting and violating life through the force of custom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:94
verses.text: "The earth is the Lord's," it is said, "and the fulness thereof".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:95
verses.text: Then why darest thou, while luxuriating in the bounties of the Lord, to ignore the Sovereign Ruler? "Leave my earth," the Lord will say to thee.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:96
verses.text: "Touch not the water which I bestow.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:97
verses.text: Partake not of the fruits of the earth produced by my husbandry".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:98
verses.text: Give to God recompense for your sustenance; acknowledge thy Master.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:99
verses.text: Thou art God's creature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:100
verses.text: What belongs to Him, how can it with justice be alienated? For that which is alienated, being deprived of the properties that belonged to it, is also deprived of truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:101
verses.text: For, after the fashion of Niobe, or, to express myself more mystically, like the Hebrew woman called by the ancients Lot's wife, are ye not turned into a state of insensibility? This woman, we have heard, was turned into stone for her love of Sodom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:102
verses.text: And those who are godless, addicted to impiety, hard-hearted and foolish, are Sodomites.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:103
verses.text: Believe that these utterances are addressed to you from God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:104
verses.text: For think not that stones, and stocks, and birds, and serpents are sacred things, and men are not; but, on the contrary, regard men as truly sacred, and take beasts and stones for what they are.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:105
verses.text: For there are miserable wretches of human kind, who consider that God utters His voice by the raven and the jackdaw, but says nothing by man; and honour the raven as a messenger of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:106
verses.text: But the man of God, who croaks not, nor chatters, but speaks rationally and instructs lovingly, alas, they persecute; and while he is inviting them to cultivate righteousness, they try inhumanly to slay him, neither welcoming the grace which comes from above, nor fearing the penalty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:107
verses.text: For they believe not God, nor understand His power, whose love to man is ineffable; and His hatred of evil is inconceivable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:108
verses.text: His anger augments punishment against sin; His love bestows blessings on repentance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:109
verses.text: It is the height of wretchedness to be deprived of the help which comes from God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:110
verses.text: Hence this blindness of eyes and dulness of hearing are more grievous than other inflictions of the evil one; for the one deprives them of heavenly vision, the other robs them of divine instruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:111
verses.text: But ye, thus maimed as respects the truth, blind in mind, deaf in understanding, are not grieved, are not pained, have had no desire to see heaven and the Maker of heaven, nor, by fixing your choice on salvation, have sought to hear the Creator of the universe, and to learn of Him; for no hindrance stands in the way of him who is bent on the knowledge of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:112
verses.text: Neither childlessness, nor poverty, nor obscurity, nor want, can hinder him who eagerly strives after the knowledge of God; nor does any one who has conquered by brass or iron the true wisdom for himself choose to exchange it, for it is vastly preferred to everything else.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:113
verses.text: Christ is able to save in every place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:114
verses.text: For he that is fired with ardour and admiration for righteousness, being the lover of One who needs nothing, needs himself but little, having treasured up his bliss in nothing but himself and God, where is neither moth, robber, nor pirate, but the eternal Giver of good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:115
verses.text: With justice, then, have you been compared to those serpents who shut their ears against the charmers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:116
verses.text: For "their mind," says the Scripture, "is like the serpent, like the deaf adder, which stoppeth her ear, and will not hear the voice of the charmers".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:117
verses.text: But allow yourselves to feel the influence of the charming strains of sanctity, and receive that mild word of ours, and reject the deadly poison, that it may be granted to you to divest yourselves as much as possible of destruction, as they have been divested of old age.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:118
verses.text: Hear me, and do not stop your ears; do not block up the avenues of hearing, but lay to heart what is said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:119
verses.text: Excellent is the medicine of immortality! Stop at length your grovelling reptile motions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:120
verses.text: "For the enemies of the Lord," says Scripture, "shall lick the dust".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:121
verses.text: Raise your eyes from earth to the skies, look up to heaven, admire the sight, cease watching with outstretched head the heel of the righteous, and hindering the way of truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:122
verses.text: Be wise and harmless.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:123
verses.text: Perchance the Lord will endow you with the wing of simplicity (for He has resolved to give wings to those that are earth-born), that you may leave your holes and dwell in heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:124
verses.text: Only let us with our whole heart repent, that we may be able with our whole heart to contain God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:125
verses.text: "Trust in Him, all ye assembled people; pour out all your hearts before Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:126
verses.text: He says to those that have newly abandoned wickedness, "He pities them, and fills them with righteousness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:127
verses.text: Believe Him who is man and God; believe, O man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:128
verses.text: Believe, O man, the living God, who suffered and is adored.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:129
verses.text: Believe, ye slaves, Him who died; believe, all ye of human kind, Him who alone is God of all men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:130
verses.text: Believe, and receive salvation as your reward.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:131
verses.text: Seek God, and your soul shall live.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:132
verses.text: He who seeks God is busying himself about his own salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:133
verses.text: Hast thou found God?—then thou hast life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:134
verses.text: Let us then seek, in order that we may live.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:135
verses.text: The reward of seeking is life with God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:136
verses.text: "Let all who seek Thee be glad and rejoice in Thee; and let them say continually, God be magnified".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:137
verses.text: A noble hymn of God is an immortal man, established in righteousness, in whom the oracles of truth are engraved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:138
verses.text: For where but in a soul that is wise can you write truth? where love? where reverence? where meekness? Those who have had these divine  characters impressed on them, ought, I think, to regard wisdom as a fair port whence to embark, to whatever lot in life they turn; and likewise to deem it the calm haven of salvation: wisdom, by which those who have betaken themselves to the Father, have proved good fathers to their children; and good parents to their sons, those who have known the Son; and good husbands to their wives, those who remember the Bridegroom; and good masters to their servants, those who have been redeemed from utter slavery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:139
verses.text: Oh, happier far the beasts than men involved in error! who live in ignorance as you, but do not counterfeit the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:140
verses.text: There are no tribes of flatterers among them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:141
verses.text: Fishes have no superstition: the birds worship not a single image; only they look with admiration on heaven, since, deprived as they are of reason, they are unable to know God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:142
verses.text: So are you not ashamed for living through so many periods of life in impiety, making yourselves more irrational than irrational creatures? You were boys, then striplings, then youths, then men, but never as yet were you good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:143
verses.text: If you have respect for old age, be wise, now that you have reached life's sunset; and albeit at the close of life, acquire the knowledge of God, that the end of life may to you prove the beginning of salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:144
verses.text: You have become old in superstition; as young, enter on the practice of piety.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:145
verses.text: God regards you as innocent children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:146
verses.text: Let, then, the Athenian follow the laws of Solon, and the Argive those of Phoroneus, and the Spartan those of Lycurgus: but if thou enrol thyself as one of God's people, heaven is thy country, God thy lawgiver.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:147
verses.text: And what are the laws? "Thou shalt not kill; thou shalt not commit adultery; thou shalt not seduce boys; thou shalt not steal; thou shalt not bear false witness; thou shalt love the Lord thy God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:148
verses.text: And the complements of these are those laws of reason and words of sanctity which are inscribed on men's hearts: "Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself; to him who strikes thee on the cheek, present also the other;" "thou shalt not lust, for by lust alone thou hast committed adultery".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:149
verses.text: How much better, therefore, is it for men from the beginning not to wish to desire things forbidden, than to obtain their desires! But ye are not able to endure the austerity of salvation; but as we delight in sweet things, and prize them higher for the agreeableness of the pleasure they yield, while, on the other hand, those bitter things which are distasteful to the palate are curative and healing, and the harshness of medicines strengthens people of weak stomach, thus custom pleases and tickles; but custom pushes into the abyss, while truth conducts to heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:150
verses.text: Harsh it is at first, but a good nurse of youth; and it is at once the decorous place where the household maids and matrons dwell together, and the sage council-chamber.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:151
verses.text: Nor is it difficult to approach, or impossible to attain, but is very near us in our very homes; as Moses, endowed with all wisdom, says, while referring to it, it has its abode in three departments of our constitution—in the hands, the mouth, and the heart: a meet emblem this of truth, which is embraced by these three things in all—will, action, speech.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:152
verses.text: And be not afraid lest the multitude of pleasing objects which rise before you withdraw you from wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:153
verses.text: You yourself will spontaneously surmount the frivolousness of custom, as boys when they have become men throw aside their toys.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:154
verses.text: For with a celerity unsurpassable, and a benevolence to which we have ready access, the divine power, casting its radiance on the earth, hath filled the universe with the seed of salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:155
verses.text: For it was not without divine care that so great a work was accomplished in so brief a space by the Lord, who, though despised as to appearance, was in reality adored, the expiator of sin, the Saviour, the clement, the Divine Word, He that is truly most manifest Deity, He that is made equal to the Lord of the universe; because He was His Son, and the Word was in God, not disbelieved in by all when He was first preached, nor altogether unknown when, assuming the character of man, and fashioning Himself in flesh, He enacted the drama of human salvation: for He was a true champion and a fellow-champion with the creature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:156
verses.text: And being communicated most speedily to men, having dawned from His Father's counsel quicker than the sun, with the most perfect ease He made God shine on us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 10:157
verses.text: Whence He was and what He was, He showed by what He taught and exhibited, manifesting Himself as the Herald of the Covenant, the Reconciler, our Saviour, the Word, the Fount of life, the Giver of peace, diffused over the whole face of the earth; by whom, so to speak, the universe has already become an ocean of blessings.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 11—How Great are the Benefits Conferred on Man Through the Advent of Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:2
verses.text: Contemplate a little, if agreeable to you, the divine beneficence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:3
verses.text: The first man, when in Paradise, sported free, because he was the child of God; but when he succumbed to pleasure (for the serpent allegorically signifies pleasure crawling on its belly, earthly wickedness nourished  for fuel to the flames), was as a child seduced by lusts, and grew old in disobedience; and by disobeying his Father, dishonoured God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:4
verses.text: Such was the influence of pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:5
verses.text: Man, that had been free by reason of simplicity, was found fettered to sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:6
verses.text: The Lord then wished to release him from his bonds, and clothing Himself with flesh—O divine mystery!—vanquished the serpent, and enslaved the tyrant death; and, most marvellous of all, man that had been deceived by pleasure, and bound fast by corruption, had his hands unloosed, and was set free.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:7
verses.text: O mystic wonder! The Lord was laid low, and man rose up; and he that fell from Paradise receives as the reward of obedience something greater than Paradise—namely, heaven itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:8
verses.text: Wherefore, since the Word Himself has come to us from heaven, we need not, I reckon, go any more in search of human learning to Athens and the rest of Greece, and to Ionia.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:9
verses.text: For if we have as our teacher Him that filled the universe with His holy energies in creation, salvation, beneficence, legislation, prophecy, teaching, we have the Teacher from whom all instruction comes; and the whole world, with Athens and Greece, has already become the domain of the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:10
verses.text: For you, who believed the poetical fable which designated Minos the Cretan as the bosom friend of Zeus, will not refuse to believe that we who have become the disciples of God have received the only true wisdom; and that which the chiefs of philosophy only guessed at, the disciples of Christ have both apprehended and proclaimed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:11
verses.text: And the one whole Christ is not divided: "There is neither barbarian, nor Jew, nor Greek, neither male nor female, but a new man," transformed by God's Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:12
verses.text: Further, the other counsels and precepts are unimportant, and respect particular things,—as, for example, if one may marry, take part in public affairs, beget children; but the only command that is universal, and over the whole course of existence, at all times and in all circumstances, tends to the highest end, viz.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:13
verses.text: , life, is piety,—all that is necessary, in order that we may live for ever, being that we live in accordance with it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:14
verses.text: Philosophy, however, as the ancients say, is "a long-lived exhortation, wooing the eternal love of wisdom;" while the commandment of the Lord is far-shining, "enlightening the eyes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:15
verses.text: Receive Christ, receive sight, receive thy light,  "In order that you may know well both God and man".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:16
verses.text: "Sweet is the Word that gives us light, precious above gold and gems; it is to be desired above honey and the honey-comb".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:17
verses.text: For how can it be other than desirable, since it has filled with light the mind which had been buried in darkness, and given keenness to the "light-bringing eyes" of the soul? For just as, had the sun not been in existence, night would have brooded over the universe notwithstanding the other luminaries of heaven; so, had we nor known the Word, and been illuminated by Him; we should have been nowise different from fowls that are being fed, fattened in darkness, and nourished for death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:18
verses.text: Let us then admit the light, that we may admit God; let us admit the light, and become disciples to the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:19
verses.text: This, too, He has been promised to the Father: "I will declare Thy name to my brethren; in the midst of the Church will I praise Thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:20
verses.text: Praise and declare to me Thy Father God; Thy utterances save; Thy hymn teaches that hitherto I have wandered in error, seeking God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:21
verses.text: But since Thou leadest me to the light, O Lord, and I find God through Thee, and receive the Father from Thee, I become "Thy fellow-heir," since Thou "wert not ashamed of me as Thy brother".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:22
verses.text: Let us put away, then, let us put away oblivion of the truth, viz.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:23
verses.text: , ignorance; and removing the darkness which obstructs, as dimness of sight, let us contemplate the only true God, first raising our voice in this hymn of praise: Hail, O light!
