For in us, buried in darkness, shut up in the shadow of death, light has shone forth from heaven, purer than the sun, sweeter than life here below.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:24
verses.text: That light is eternal life; and whatever partakes of it lives.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:25
verses.text: But night fears the light, and hiding itself in terror, gives place to the day of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:26
verses.text: Sleepless light is now over all, and the west has given credence to the east.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:27
verses.text: For this was the end of the new creation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:28
verses.text: For "the Sun of Righteousness," who drives His chariot over all, pervades equally all humanity, like "His Father, who makes His sun to rise on all men," and distils on them the dew of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:29
verses.text: He hath changed sunset into sunrise, and through the cross brought death to life; and having wrenched man from destruction, He hath raised him to the skies, transplanting mortality into immortality, and translating earth to heaven—He, the husbandman of God,  "Pointing out the favourable signs and rousing the nations To good works, putting them in mind of the true sustenance;"  having bestowed on us the truly great, divine, and inalienable inheritance of the Father, deifying man by heavenly teaching, putting His laws  into our minds, and writing them on our hearts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:30
verses.text: What laws does He inscribe? "That all shall know God, from small to great;" and, "I will be merciful to them," says God, "and will not remember their sins".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:31
verses.text: Let us receive the laws of life, let us comply with God's expostulations; let us become acquainted with Him, that He may be gracious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:32
verses.text: And though God needs nothing let us render to Him the grateful recompense of a thankful heart and of piety, as a kind of house-rent for our dwelling here below.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:33
verses.text: "Gold for brass, A hundred oxen's worth for that of nine;"  that is, for your little faith He gives you the earth of so great extent to till, water to drink and also to sail on, air to breathe, fire to do your work, a world to dwell in; and He has permitted you to conduct a colony from here to heaven: with these important works of His hand, and benefits in such numbers, He has rewarded your little faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:34
verses.text: Then, those who have put faith in necromancers, receive from them amulets and charms, to ward off evil forsooth; and will you not allow the heavenly Word, the Saviour, to be bound on to you as an amulet, and, by trusting in God's own charm, be delivered from passions which are the diseases of the mind, and rescued from sin?—for sin is eternal death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:35
verses.text: Surely utterly dull and blind, and, like moles, doing nothing but eat, you spend your lives in darkness, surrounded with corruption.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:36
verses.text: But it is truth which cries, "The light shall shine forth from the darkness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:37
verses.text: Let the light then shine in the hidden part of man, that is, the heart; and let the beams of knowledge arise to reveal and irradiate the hidden inner man, the disciple of the Light, the familiar friend and fellow-heir of Christ; especially now that we have come to know the most precious and venerable name of the good Father, who to a pious and good child gives gentle counsels, and commands what is salutary for His child.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:38
verses.text: He who obeys Him has the advantage in all things, follows God, obeys the Father, knows Him through wandering, loves God, loves his neighbour, fulfils the commandment, seeks the prize, claims the promise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:39
verses.text: But it has been God's fixed and constant purpose to save the flock of men: for this end the good God sent the good Shepherd.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:40
verses.text: And the Word, having unfolded the truth, showed to men the height of salvation, that either repenting they might be saved, or refusing to obey, they might be judged.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:41
verses.text: This is the proclamation of righteousness: to those that obey, glad tidings; to those that disobey, judgment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:42
verses.text: The loud trumpet, when sounded, collects the soldiers, and proclaims war.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:43
verses.text: And shall not Christ, breathing a strain of peace to the ends of the earth, gather together His own soldiers, the soldiers of peace? Well, by His blood, and by the word, He has gathered the bloodless host of peace, and assigned to them the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:44
verses.text: The trumpet of Christ is His Gospel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:45
verses.text: He hath blown it, and we have heard.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:46
verses.text: "Let us array ourselves in the armour of peace, putting on the breastplate of righteousness, and taking the shield of faith, and binding our brows with the helmet of salvation; and the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God," let us sharpen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:47
verses.text: So the apostle in the spirit of peace commands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:48
verses.text: These are our invulnerable weapons: armed with these, let us face the evil one; "the fiery darts of the evil one" let us quench with the sword-points dipped in water, that, have been baptized by the Word, returning grateful thanks for the benefits we have received, and honouring God through the Divine Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:49
verses.text: "For while thou art yet speaking," it is said, "He will say, Behold, I am beside thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:50
verses.text: O this holy and blessed power, by which God has fellowship with men! Better far, then, is it to become at once the imitator and the servant of the best of all beings; for only by holy service will any one be able to imitate God, and to serve and worship Him only by imitating Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:51
verses.text: The heavenly and truly divine love comes to men thus, when in the soul itself the spark of true goodness, kindled in the soul by the Divine Word, is able to burst forth into flame; and, what is of the highest importance, salvation runs parallel with sincere willingness—choice and life being, so to speak, yoked together.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:52
verses.text: Wherefore this exhortation of the truth alone, like the most faithful of our friends, abides with us till our last breath, and is to the whole and perfect spirit of the soul the kind attendant on our ascent to heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:53
verses.text: What, then, is the exhortation I give you? I urge you to be saved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:54
verses.text: This Christ desires.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:55
verses.text: In one word, He freely bestows life on you.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:56
verses.text: And who is He? Briefly learn.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:57
verses.text: The Word of truth, the Word of incorruption, that regenerates man by bringing him back to the truth—the goad that urges to salvation—He who expels destruction and pursues death—He who builds up the temple of God in men, that He may cause God to take up His abode in men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 11:58
verses.text: Cleanse the temple; and pleasures and amusements abandon to the winds and the fire, as a fading flower; but wisely cultivate the fruits of self-command, and present thyself to God as an offering of first-fruits, that there may be not the work alone, but also the grace of God; and both are requisite, that the friend of Christ may be rendered worthy of the kingdom, and be counted worthy of the kingdom.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 12—Exhortation to Abandon Their Old Errors and Listen to the Instructions of Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:2
verses.text: Let us then avoid custom as we would a dangerous headland, or the threatening Charybdis, or the mythic sirens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:3
verses.text: It chokes man, turns him away from truth, leads him away from life: custom is a snare, a gulf, a pit, a mischievous winnowing fan.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:4
verses.text: "Urge the ship beyond that smoke and billow".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:5
verses.text: Let us shun, fellow-mariners, let us shun this billow; it vomits forth fire: it is a wicked island, heaped with bones and corpses, and in it sings a fair courtesan, Pleasure, delighting with music for the common ear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:6
verses.text: "Hie thee hither, far-famed Ulysses, great glory of the Achaeans; Moor the ship, that thou mayest hears diviner voice".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:7
verses.text: She praises thee, O mariner, and calls the eillustrious; and the courtesan tries to win to herself the glory of the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:8
verses.text: Leave her to prey on the dead; a heavenly spirit comes to thy help: pass by Pleasure, she beguiles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:9
verses.text: "Let not a woman with flowing train cheat you of your senses, With her flattering prattle seeking your hurt".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:10
verses.text: Sail past the song; it works death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:11
verses.text: Exert your will only, and you have overcome ruin; bound to the wood of the cross, thou shalt be freed from destruction: the word of God will be thy pilot, and the Holy Spirit will bring thee to anchor in the haven of heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:12
verses.text: Then shalt thou see my God, and be initiated into the sacred mysteries, and come to the fruition of those things which are laid up in heaven reserved for me, which "ear hath not heard, nor have they entered into the heart of any".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:13
verses.text: "And in sooth methinks I see two suns, And a double Thebes,"  said one frenzy-stricken in the worship of idols, intoxicated with mere ignorance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:14
verses.text: I would pity him in his frantic intoxication, and thus frantic I would invite him to the sobriety of salvation; for the Lord welcomes a sinner's repentance, and not his death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:15
verses.text: Come, O madman, not leaning on the thyrsus, not crowned with ivy; throw away the mitre, throw away the fawn-skin; come to thy senses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:16
verses.text: I will show thee the Word, and the mysteries of the Word, expounding them after thine own fashion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:17
verses.text: This is the mountain beloved of God, not the subject of tragedies like Cithaeron, but consecrated to dramas of the truth,—a mount of sobriety, shaded with forests of purity; and there revel on it not the Maenades, the sisters of Semele, who was struck by the thunderbolt, practising in their initiatory rites unholy division of flesh, but the daughters of God, the fair lambs, who celebrate the holy rites of the Word, raising a sober choral dance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:18
verses.text: The righteous are the chorus; the music is a hymn of the King of the universe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:19
verses.text: The maidens strike the lyre, the angels praise, the prophets speak; the sound of music issues forth, they run and pursue the jubilant band; those that are called make haste, eagerly desiring to receive the Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:20
verses.text: Come thou also, O aged man, leaving Thebes, and casting away from thee both divination and Bacchic frenzy, allow thyself to be led to the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:21
verses.text: I give thee the staff of the cross on which to lean.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:22
verses.text: Haste, Tiresias; believe, and thou wilt see.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:23
verses.text: Christ, by whom the eyes of the blind recover sight, will shed on thee a light brighter than the sun; night will flee from thee, fire will fear, death will be gone; thou, old man, who saw not Thebes, shalt see the heavens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:24
verses.text: O truly sacred mysteries! O stainless light! My way is lighted with torches, and I survey the heavens and God; I become holy whilst I am initiated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:25
verses.text: The Lord is the hierophant, and seals while illuminating him who is initiated, and presents to the Father him who believes, to be kept safe for ever.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:26
verses.text: Such are the reveries of my mysteries.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:27
verses.text: If it is thy wish, be thou also initiated; and thou shall join the choir along with angels around the unbegotten and indestructible and the only true God, the Word of God, raising the hymn with us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:28
verses.text: This Jesus, who is eternal, the one great High Priest of the one God, and of His Father, prays for and exhorts men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:29
verses.text: "Hear, ye myriad tribes, rather whoever among men are endowed with reason, both barbarians and Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:30
verses.text: I call on the whole race of men, whose Creator I am, by the will of the Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:31
verses.text: Come to Me, that you may be put in your due rank under the one God and the one Word of God; and do not only have the advantage of the irrational creatures in the possession of reason; for to you of all mortals I grant the enjoyment of immortality.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:32
verses.text: For I want, I want to impart to you this grace, bestowing on you the perfect boon of immortality; and I confer on you both the Word and the knowledge of God, My complete self.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:33
verses.text: This am I, this God wills, this is symphony, this the harmony of the Father, this is the Son, this is Christ, this the Word of God, the arm of the Lord, the power of the universe, the will of the Father; of which things there were images of old, but not all adequate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:34
verses.text: I desire to restore you according to the original model, that ye may become also like Me.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:35
verses.text: I anoint you with the ungent of faith, by which you throw off corruption,  and show you the naked form of righteousness by which you ascend to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:36
verses.text: Come to Me, all ye that labour and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:37
verses.text: Take My yoke upon you, and learn of Me; for I am meek and lowly in heart: and ye shall find rest to your souls.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:38
verses.text: For My yoke is easy, and My burden light".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:39
verses.text: Let us haste, let us run, my fellow-men—us, who are God-loving and God-like images of the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:40
verses.text: Let us haste, let us run, let us take His yoke, let us receive, to conduct us to immortality, the good charioteer of men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:41
verses.text: Let us love Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:42
verses.text: He led the colt with its parent; and having yoked the team of humanity to God, directs His chariot to immortality, hastening clearly to fulfil, by driving now into heaven, what He shadowed forth before by riding into Jerusalem.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:43
verses.text: A spectacle most beautiful to the Father is the eternal Son crowned with victory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:44
verses.text: Let us aspire, then, after what is good; let us become God-loving men, and obtain the greatest of all things which are incapable of being harmed—God and life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:45
verses.text: Our helper is the Word; let us put confidence in Him; and never let us be visited with such a craving for silver and gold, and glory, as for the Word of truth Himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:46
verses.text: For it will not, it will not be pleasing to God Himself if we value least those things which are worth most, and hold in the highest estimation the manifest enormities and the utter impiety of folly, and ignorance, and thoughtlessness, and idolatry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:47
verses.text: For not improperly the sons of the philosophers consider that the foolish are guilty of profanity and impiety in whatever they do; and describing ignorance itself as a species of madness, allege that the multitude are nothing but madmen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:48
verses.text: There is therefore no room to doubt, the Word will say, whether it is better to be sane or insane; but holding on to truth with our teeth, we must with all our might follow God, and in the exercise of wisdom regard all things to be, as they are, His; and besides, having learned that we are the most excellent of His possessions, let us commit ourselves to God, loving the Lord God, and regarding this as our business all our life long.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:49
verses.text: And if what belongs to friends be reckoned common property, and man be the friend of God—for through the mediation of the Word has he been made the friend of God—then accordingly all things become man's, because all things are God's, and the common property of both the friends, God and man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:50
verses.text: It is time, then, for us to say that the pious Christian alone is rich and wise, and of noble birth, and thus call and believe him to be God's image, and also His likeness, having become righteous and holy and wise by Jesus Christ, and so far already like God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:51
verses.text: Accordingly this grace is indicated by the prophet, when he says, "I said that ye are gods, and all sons of the Highest".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:52
verses.text: For us, yea us, He has adopted, and wishes to be called the Father of us alone, not of the unbelieving.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:53
verses.text: Such is then our position who are the attendants of Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:54
verses.text: "As are men's wishes, so are their words; As are their words, so are their deeds; And as their works, such is their life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:55
verses.text: Good is the whole life of those who have known Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:56
verses.text: Enough, methinks, of words, though, impelled by love to man, I might have gone on to pour out what I had from God, that I might exhort to what is the greatest of blessings—salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:57
verses.text: For discourses concerning the life which has no end, are not readily brought to the end of their disclosures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:58
verses.text: To you still remains this conclusion, to choose which will profit you most—judgment or grace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: Exhortation to the Heathen 12:59
verses.text: For I do not think there is even room for doubt which of these is the better; nor is it allowable to compare life with destruction.
